title: Chinese Government grants $764,526 of humanitarian aids for natural disaster relief in Tajikistan
description: In 2011, Chinese Government granted $764,526 USD to Tajikistan in the form of humanitarian aid for flooding and other natural disasters, according to the May 2018 Flat Export of the Tajikistan AIMS, 'Humanitarian aid for flood and other disasters', AIMS project ID is TJK/112260. Though the Flat Export does not tie this project to a specific disaster, it is possible that the referenced flooding was a series of June 2011 floods and mudslides in Sughd Province (see 'Tajikistan: Floods and Mudslides - Jun 2011'). STAFF_NOTE: This project should not be confused with project ID#40441, the 2012 natural disaster response from China to Tajikistan. The 2012 aid package primarily sought to address the impact of an unusually cold winter, while the 2011 aid package primarily sought to address the impact of a flood.
sources: https://reliefweb.int/disaster/ff-2011-000066-tjk, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; https://www.dropbox.com/s/rl546mymjz3f15f/May%202018%20Flat%20Export%20from%20Tajikistan%20AIMS%20China%20Specific%20Projects.xlsx?dl=0 , Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: China sent humanitarian aid to Tajikistan to deal with mudslides. Sughd Province experienced the mudslides and other disasters. While the source said there were 3 specific districts, I could not find them so I coded up to the ADM1.

title: China Eximbank provides $8.36 million government concessional loan for Safe City Project (Linked to Project ID#71411)
description:
On May 20, 2013, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed two loan agreements with the Export-Import Bank of China for the Safe City Project: a RMB-denominated government concessional loan (GCL) provided on highly concessional terms (20-year maturity, 11-year grace period, and 1.5% interest rate) and a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan on highly concessional terms (2% interest, 20-year maturity, 9-year grace period).

The precise face value of the GCL loan and the precise face value of the PBC loan are unknown. However, it is known that the GCL and PBC are jointly worth $20.9 million USD, and that 40% of the total debt financing from China Eximbank ($8.36 million) came from the RMB-denominated GCL and 60% of the total debt financing from China Eximbank ($12.54 million) came from the USD-denominated PBC (AidData learned this through correspondence with the IMF, see "Following Up" resource). Project ID#46215 records the GCL and project ID#71411 records the PBC. 

The loans were ratified by the Tajik Parliament in June 2013 and were expected to be repaid with revenues from the traffic fines generated by this project. The total cost of the project was $22 million USD. In addition to the Chinese loans, the Government of Tajikistan contributed $1.1 million USD.

According to Ministry of Internal Affairs of the Republic of Tajikistan, the Safe City Project involved the installation of 855 CCTV cameras for round-the-clock monitoring of traffic and other movements at 75 crossroads, streets, and squares in the capital city of Dushanbe. The cameras were to record every offense committed by drivers, which would be stored and processed in a common database. Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd. was responsible for project implementation. Tajik Ministry of Internal Affairs was also responsible for the undertaking of the project. 

The Safe City project and the control center were officially launched on October 31, 2013 by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. The Safe City Project was to be carried out in three stages; the second stage was expected to be finished in May 2014. The project was still on going as of December 2014. As of January 16, 2015, it had reportedly generated $4 million for the Tajik state budget via traffic fines. According to a Huawei report issued in February 2015, Huawei completed the project successfully. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Автоматическая система управления транспорта в городе Душанбе (Безопасный город). Asia Plus reported at the time that Tajikistan authorities claimed the loan would be repayable through traffic violation fines.

GEO_notes: Dushanbe was part of the Safe City Project, which involved 855 CCTV cameras being installed. The city of Dushanbe is a weird case because the city is part of the Districts under Central Government Jurisdiction, which are coded as ADM1s. It is further divided into four districts but, because the cameras were installed all over the city, I coded the Rudaki Capital District.

title: China Eximbank provides $118 million USD loan for 15,000 Hectares Agricultural Industrial Park Project and 200,000 Spindle Textile Project (Linked to Project ID#54353, #71757)
description:
In June 2016 , at the 2016 Silk Road Financial Forum in Warsaw, Poland, the Xinjiang Branch of the Export-Import Bank of China signed a framework agreement with Xinjiang Zhongtai (Group) Co., Ltd for the 15,000 Hectares Agricultural Industrial Park Project and 200,000 Spindle Textile Project. Then, a commissioning ceremony for the project took place on August 31, 2016. China Eximbank provided a $118.343 million loan in 2016 to Zhongtai (Dangara) New Silk Road Textile Industry Company for the 15,000 Hectares Agricultural Industrial Park Project and 200,000 Spindle Textile Project. 

Zhongtai (Dangara) New Silk Road Textile Industry Company is the company responsible for project implementation. Zhongtai (Dangara) New Silk Road Textile Industry Co., Ltd. was founded in the Dangara District of Tajikistan's Khatlon Province in 2014 by China's Xinjiang Zhongtai Group and Xinjiang Production and Construction Corps. The Zhongtai Dangara Agriculture and Textile Industrial Park project consisted of an agricultural park with 15,000 hectares for growing cotton; a spinning plant with 110,000 spindles and manufacturing facilities for weaving, printing and garment. The groundbreaking ceremony of the entire Agricultural and Textile Project was held on December 19, 2014 ("中泰新丝路塔吉克斯坦农业纺织产业园奠基"). The second phase, including the start of the airflow of 50,000 spindles, was to be completed in 2017 (see "塔吉克斯坦总理科希尔·拉苏尔佐达一行考察中泰集团公司"). The launch ceremony of the second phase of the air spindles was held, and the third phase held its groundbreaking ceremony on November 5, 2018. The third and fourth phases started on March 18, 2019.

The Agricultural and Textile Industrial Park project was reportedly the largest agricultural and textile investment project in Tajikistan since its independence in 1991. The project included 200,000 mu of cotton agricultural park and 150,000 spinning spindles. The first phase of 150,000 mu of cotton was to be sown in 2015, and the spinning project was to be completed and put into operation on August 31, 2016. After the project is completed, the industrial park was expected to be able to produce 80,000 tons of seed cotton, 32,000 tons of lint, 24,000 tons of cotton yarn, 91.5 million meters of cotton cloth, annual sales revenue of RMB 1.525 billion, and a profit of RMB 250 million, improving the welfare of its workers and driving industrial and agricultural development in Tajikistan. 

For a RMB 1.1 billion investment by Chinese companies for industrial park, see linked to project #54353. For a RMB 200 million loan for the industrial park from the Agricultural Bank of China, please see linked project ID#71757.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 新疆中泰集团有限公司1.5万公顷农业产 业园及20万锭纺织项目. One official source ("金融论坛取得丰硕跨境务实成果") suggests that the face value of the loan was $130 million USD, but we have chosen the more conservative of the two estimates for the time being. It is unclear which phase of the project was funded by this Eximbank loan, or if it was a general loan.
sources: https://web.archive.org/web/20170515154926/http://english.eximbank.gov.cn/tm/en-AR/index_634_30016.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.eximbank.gov.cn/aboutExim/annals/2016/201807/P020180712402151419837.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://web.archive.org/web/20170201213052/http://www.xjgzw.gov.cn/info/1069/6506.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.xinhuanet.com/world/2019-06/10/c_1210155281.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://pdf.dfcfw.com/pdf/H2_AN201609090017579115_1.pdf, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.sohu.com/a/296848969_754816, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.srfinance.org.cn/index.php?m=content&c=index&a=show&catid=427&id=501, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2019-06/13/c_138138259.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dropbox.com/s/hz9phzl5utk5biv/rieter-zhongtai-dangara-reference-millbrochure-en-3009-87536.pdf?dl=0, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.dropbox.com/s/o73wxg53o6oo07z/Experience.pdf?dl=0, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://world.people.com.cn/n/2014/1221/c157278-26246325.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.cctv.com/2018/05/31/ARTIx8kpqfM0z0E5XB34kZBu180531.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.abchina.com/en/AboutUs/csr-report/201904/P020190925352626015065.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://m.sinotex.cn/read.asp?id=147153, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCCA00020181106eeb6000b5&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks
location_details: This project involved the construction of an agricultural industrial park and a large cotton processing and textile producing enterprise in Dangara District within Tajikistan's Khatlon Province.
GEO_notes: China funded an agricultural industrial park and a large cotton processing and textile producing plant. These enterprises are located in Danghara District.

title: China Construction Bank provides $100 million loan to refinance 2012 CNMIM loan to China Nonferrous Gold Limited for Pakrut Gold Project (Linked to Project ID#54361, #70174, #70220, #70319, #70324, #70354, #70407, #70430)
description:
On May 24, 2012, China Nonferrous Metals International Mining Co. Ltd (CNMIM) provided a secured loan facility on commercial terms to Kryso Resources PLC — the mineral exploration and development company developing the Pakrut Gold Project — for $10 million and RMB 530 million to finance the development of the Pakrut Gold Project (see linked Project ID#70174 and #70319). Then, on June 19, 2014, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Macau) Limited provided a $120 million term loan facility to China Nonferrous Mining Group for the Pakrut Gold Project (see linked Project ID#70220). Then, on May 6, 2016, China Nonferrous Mining Group obtained a loan facility $120 million from CNMC International Capitals Company Limited (“CNMC”)— an associate of CNMIM — to refinance the loan facility that it contracted with Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Macau) Limited on June 19, 2014 for the Pakrut Gold Project (see linked Project ID#70324). On June 27, 2016 the China Nonferrous Mining Group obtained another loan, worth $19,114,809, from CNMIM for working capital purposes related to the Pakrut Gold Project (see linked Project ID#70354).

Then, on July 1, 2016, China Construction Bank Corporation Macau Branch (CCBC) provided a loan facility of $100 million to China Nonferrous Mining Group to refinance its 2012 loan agreement with CNMIM (see linked Projects IDs #70174 and #70319) and also for working capital purposes. The CCBC loan was for a maximum of 5 years (5-year maturity) and was repayable 60 months from the date of first drawdown. The annual interest rate was 3-month LIBOR plus a 2.1% margin (see "Interim Results" from September 30, 2016). The average 3-month LIBOR rate in July 2016 was 0.696%. Therefore, the interest rate was coded as 0.696+2.1=2.796%.

According to "CNG: China Nonferrous Gold Limited: Annual Report and Account" published on July 1, 2019, the loan was secured by Standby Letter(s) of Credit issued by China Construction Bank Corporation, Beijing Branch, and guaranteed by CNMC under the terms of the loan agreement, for an aggregate amount of not less than US$103,092,783.51, with validity of not less than 60 months in favor of CCB. The loan was fully drawn down in 2016. 

The loan was repayable in 8 installments commencing 18 months from the drawdown date. The repayment schedule was as follows, denominated in USD (taken from "CNG: China Nonferrous Gold Limited: Annual Report and Account" on Bloomberg):
- December 31, 2017 – $5,000,000 (payment made in January 2018)
- June 30, 2018 – $5,000,000
- December 31, 2018 – $5,000,000
- June 30, 2019 – $5,000,000
- December 31, 2019 – $5,000,000
- June 30, 2020 – $5,000,000
- December 31, 2020 – $5,000,000
- June 30, 2021 (or 14 working days prior to the expiry date of relevant Standby Letter(s) of Credit – whichever is earlier)

LLC Pakrut, a mine that is 100% owned by Kryso Resources Ltd, was first established in 2003 and it operates the Pakrut deposit located on the southern slope of the Gissar range, 107 km from the city of Dushanbe. The geological exploration at Pakrut deposit started in 2004. The pre-gold reserves at the deposit, approved by the State Reserves Committee (CRC) of the Republic of Tajikistan, were 28.1 tons. The reserves of Pakrut gold mine are currently estimated to be 100 tons. In November 2011, the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan issued a mining licence to LLC Pakrut. Construction started in September 2012. The project went into production on June 5, 2016. In February 2017, high levels of snowfall caused significant damage to the facilities and equipment, and interrupted the construction, which was restarted in the second half of 2017. All construction work was expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2018 and production was expected to be recommenced in April 2018.

This mining project is located in Vahdat District, Republic of Tajikistan, about 80 km northeast (“NE”) in a straight line (112 km by road) from Dushanbe, the country’s capital city. It sits on the southern slope of the Gissar range. More detailed locational information can be found at http://www.cnfgold.com/Managed/Resources/docs/Downloads/srk_report.pdf.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is "塔吉克斯坦帕克鲁特金矿."

title: China launched 'Hundred Talents Program' for training professional technical personnel for Central-Asia Natural Gas Project (Linked to project ID##39955, #70616)
description: On October 10, 2017, Xi'an Shiyou University of China held the launching ceremony of the 'Hundred Talents Program'. In 2016, Xi'an Shiyou University successfully won the bid for the TTGP foreign employee training project. After the launching of Central-Asia Natural Gas Project (captured in #39955), according to the agreement between the governments of China and Tajikistan, China will train 90 relevant professional localized technical personnel for Tajikistan. Therefore, TTGP actively sought out Chinese partner universities to undertake the localized staff training tasks required for the construction and operation of the pipeline. According to the agreement, the company will select the first group of 30 students from Tajikistan to come to China to study Chinese language and oil and gas pipeline transportation and other professional academic education, and become the first group of students to come to China in the TTGP China-Tajikistan school-enterprise cooperation talent training project 'Hundred Talents Program'. The first thirty students to receive the training were selected from the 1,000 top students, with the assistance of National Testing Center of Tajikistan, and China National Natural Gas Pipeline Co., Ltd., under the approval of the Deputy Prime Minister of Tajikistan. The students will take Chinese language courses in Tianjin University for one year, and in Xi'an Shiyou University for another year. Then they will study the undergraduate major courses of oil and gas storage and transportation in Xi'an Shiyou University. After graduation, they will work professionally for the Line D of Central-Asia Natural Gas Project. Fifteen students out of thirty received scholarships of the 'Silk Road' Program from the Chinese Government. China-Central Asia natural gas pipeline Line D is an inter-governmental project signed by China, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan. The construction of the Tajikistan section of the 1,000-km-long line was launched in September 2014. Tajikistan has the longest section of the pipeline at about 410 km. For details on this project see #39955 and #70616.
sources: http://xyl.xsyu.edu.cn/xxxw/6457.jhtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNHA000020171011edab000ma&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://tj.chineseembassy.org/chn/sbgx/t1487598.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://m.jyb.cn/rmtzcg/xwy/wzxw/201908/t20190815_253298_wap.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.jyb.cn/zcg/xwy/wzxw/201710/t20171010_792174.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: China trained people from Tajikistan to work on a pipeline. The training took place outside of Tajikistan so it was coded up.

title: Chinese Embassy donates 'Gurdaston' Women's Sewing Center in Dushanbe (Linked to project ID#53594, #53591, #53587, #54043, #71881)
description:
The Chinese Embassy to Tajikistan donated the "Gurdaston" Women's Sewing Center in Dushanbe. The opening ceremony was held on June 30, 2017. The center was intended to promote women's employment and improve the prosperity and welfare of Dushanbe, according to the embassy. The value of the donated sewing center is unknown. 

Chinese Embassy also funded other differenct Women’s Sewing Training and Production Center in Tajikistan. Project ID#53594 captured the sewing center in Danghara. Project ID#54043 captured the sewing center in Maslozhelkomupo District, Dushanbe. Project ID#53591 captured the sewing center in Vakhsh District, Khatlon. Project ID#53587 captured the sewing center in Sino District, Dushanbe. Project ID#71881 captured the sewing center in the Dzhami District, Khatlon.

STAFF_NOTE: "Year uncertain" was checked because it is not confirmed that this donation was committed in 2017. "Gurdaston" is a one translation; another was "Gulda Stone", and "Gurda Stone."
sources: http://tj.chineseembassy.org/chn/sbgx/t1474409.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: China funded the Women's Sewing Center in Dushanbe. This specific Center is located in the city of Dushanbe so I coded Rudaki District.
Christian Notes: good. Description lists locations of other spots, but these are separate projects

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 58.4 million grant for Phase 1 of the Kurgan-Tyube to Kulob Road Rehabilitation Project (Linked to Project ID#53990 and #72612)
description:
In 2013, the Chinese Government agreed to provide RMB 58.4 million of grant financing for Phase 1 of the the Kurgan-Tyube to Kulob Road Rehabilitation Project (captured in project ID#71741). Then, in 2016, the Chinese Government agreed to provide RMB 59.6 million of grant financing for Phase 2 of the the Kurgan-Tyube to Kulob Road Rehabilitation Project (captured in project ID#53990).

The first phase of the project involved the construction of 12 kilometers of roads in Kurgan-Tyube and Kulob and 2 automobile bridges in Kulob. The second phase of the project involved the rehabilitation of 15 streets and 4 bridges in Kurgan-Tyube and Kulob measuring 22 km in length.

China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The project was supervised and managed by China Railway First Survey and Design Institute Group Co.,Ltd.

The first phase officially started on April 17, 2015. The inauguration ceremony and the signing ceremony of the technology handover certificate for project was held on January 19, 2016. The second phase of construction began on December 29, 2016. It was completed on December 15, 2017, after passing inspection. The Project Qualification Certificate was signed on December 27, 2007. The inaugural ceremony for the second phase was held on January 8, 2018.

STAFF_NOTE: : This project is also known as the Road Rehabilitation Project for Two Cities in Tajikistan. The Chinese project title is 塔吉克斯坦两城市道路修复项目（第II阶段).

GEO_notes: Kulob District was coded in this row. The purpose of Phase 1 was to build 2 bridges in the city of Kulob.

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 58.4 million grant for Phase 1 of the Kurgan-Tyube to Kulob Road Rehabilitation Project (Linked to Project ID#53990 and #72612)
description:
In 2013, the Chinese Government agreed to provide RMB 58.4 million of grant financing for Phase 1 of the the Kurgan-Tyube to Kulob Road Rehabilitation Project (captured in project ID#71741). Then, in 2016, the Chinese Government agreed to provide RMB 59.6 million of grant financing for Phase 2 of the the Kurgan-Tyube to Kulob Road Rehabilitation Project (captured in project ID#53990).

The first phase of the project involved the construction of 12 kilometers of roads in Kurgan-Tyube and Kulob and 2 automobile bridges in Kulob. The second phase of the project involved the rehabilitation of 15 streets and 4 bridges in Kurgan-Tyube and Kulob measuring 22 km in length.

China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The project was supervised and managed by China Railway First Survey and Design Institute Group Co.,Ltd.

The first phase officially started on April 17, 2015. The inauguration ceremony and the signing ceremony of the technology handover certificate for project was held on January 19, 2016. The second phase of construction began on December 29, 2016. It was completed on December 15, 2017, after passing inspection. The Project Qualification Certificate was signed on December 27, 2007. The inaugural ceremony for the second phase was held on January 8, 2018.

STAFF_NOTE: : This project is also known as the Road Rehabilitation Project for Two Cities in Tajikistan. The Chinese project title is 塔吉克斯坦两城市道路修复项目（第II阶段).

Christian Notes: also built bridges in Kulob. Added that district

title: China Development Bank provides a US$78 million long-term loan for Huaxin Cement's cement plant (Linked to Project ID#53588, #53976)
description: In 2011, China Development Bank (CDB) provided a US$78 million long-term loan for Huaxin Cement's construction of a dry process cement production line in Tajikistan. Huaxin Cement Company has built the country's first new dry-process cement production line in Tajikistan. This production line can produce 1 million tons of cement each year, which will greatly enhance Tajikistan's ability to build infrastructure. Total investment was 1.5 billion dollars. Huaxin launched a JV for the project. Huaxin's equity investment amount is vague. The equity part is captured in project ID#53976. Construction for Huaxin's first plant begun on September 15, 2011, and production begun on August 29, 2013. As early as August 2011, Huaxin Cement signed a cooperation agreement with Tajikistan, and the two parties planned to jointly build a new dry-process cement production line project with an annual output of 1 million tons. In 2014, Huaxin Cement's second and third cement production line projects in the tower were also launched. Among them, the second line is expected to be put into production in the first quarter of 2016. Huaxin Cement's second and third cement production line projects will be located in two cities in Tajikistan, tentatively named the Huzhande project and the Dangara project, and are planned to be completed and put into operation in 2015 and 2016 respectively. For the investment in the second and third cement production line projects plant by Huaxin Cement, please see linked project ID#53588.
sources: http://www.cdb.com.cn/English/bgxz/ndbg/ndbg2014/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://web.b.ebscohost.com.proxy.wm.edu/ehost/detail/detail?vid=0&sid=fab0c3b8-c6fc-4941-a645-b8d63e17617b%40pdc-v-sessmgr02&bdata=JkF1dGhUeXBlPWNvb2tpZSxpcCx1cmwsc2hpYiZzaXRlPWVob3N0LWxpdmUmc2NvcGU9c2l0ZQ%3d%3d#AN=123074280&db=poh, Academic Journal Article; http://finance.china.com.cn/roll/20160224/3597866.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://finance.eastmoney.com/news/1349,20140916424157083.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.p5w.net/money/yhzx/201412/t20141227_894124.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: I could not find the location of the first cement processing line. The two cities listed are for the next phases. Due to this, I had to code up to country level.
Christian Notes: heres a link w location of the plant: https://www.dropbox.com/s/reu08zd2oz3dujt/LLC%20Huaxin%20Ghayur%20Sement.%20-%20Expo%20Tajikistan.pdf?dl=0

title: Chinese Government provided a RMB 60 million grant for the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID#39989)
description:
As part of a set of high-level agreements signed at the June 15, 2006 meeting of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO), the Chinese Government offered a RMB 60 million grant for the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project (see the cited resource:"China signs Tajik loan deals"). This project was also supported by a $281.1 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan from the Export-Import Bank of China (see Project ID#39989).

Earlier, in March 2006, China and Tajikistan had signed a Memorandum of Understanding that stated the terms of preferential credits issuance for promotion of economic and social development of SCO members. One of the financing projects identified was this road project.China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on July 11, 2006. The construction period was planned to be 38 months. The highway was commissioned in 2010, but work continued on the Shahristan tunnel. The project was wholly completed on October 27, 2012, with an opening ceremony for the Shahristan tunnel that was attended by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. 

The purpose of this project — also known as the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project — was to reconstruct the 354 km highway connecting Dushanbe with Khujand, the center of the northern province, and the town of Chanak on the border with Uzbekistan. The project also involved the construction of the 5253-meter Shahristan tunnel (at a cost of $88,424), the 1047-meter Dusti tunnel, the Maikhura tunnel, 39 big and small bridges, and 6 km of avalanche defenses. More detailed locational information is available at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbe-chanak-highway-including-shahristan-and-dusty-tunnels-rehabilitation/d0fdfa30-2790-41ab-8462-fb056c335c52/.

The project reportedly reduced driving times from 12 hours to 4 hours and the Shahristan tunnel was reportedly the longest tunnel in Central Asia when it completed, according to China Global Television Network. To help repay the loan and cover the costs of maintaining the road, the Tajik Government made the highway a toll road in 2010 and allowed the private company Innovative Road Solutions to collected tolls . 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is реабилитацию автомобильной дороги «Душанбе – Чанак». The Chinese project title is 塔乌（乌兹别克斯坦）公路.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=SHND000020060614e26e00003&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=UZREPE0020060613e26e001gt&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=SHND000020060616e26g00003&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.crbc.com/site/crbcEN/381/info/2013/1796889.html?id=afd3ea85-64b2-4fa1-9289-d197e2b5d6a4, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://news.cgtn.com/news/3d3d514d79496a4d35457a6333566d54/index.html, Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs; http://en.ccccltd.cn/business/overseas/201011/t20101112_1558.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.crbc.com/site/crbcEN/381/info/2012/1566889.html?id=afd3ea85-64b2-4fa1-9289-d197e2b5d6a4, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.crbc.com/site/crbcEN/381/info/2012/1539123.html?id=afd3ea85-64b2-4fa1-9289-d197e2b5d6a4, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TEyiC5Aj-iw, Other; https://www.crbc.com/site/crbcEN/514/info/2017/46840918.html?id=570e2bf6-b830-4fd4-80d9-1c51e2336193, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://mintrans.tj/ru/road-facilities/projects/reabilitaciya-avtodorogi-dushanbe-chanak-gruzbekistan-v-tom-chisle, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/877071468303575509/pdf/891840NWP0P14700TJK0NOTE60final0web.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://www.academia.edu/11723531/_China_as_an_Emerging_Donor_in_Tajikistan_and_Kyrgyzstan_, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); http://minfin.tj/downloads/files/MTEFfinalTajikenglish.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://tnu.tj/Dissertatsii/GafurovaGA/GafurovaGA.pdf, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); http://nbt.tj/en/news/9056/, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)
factiva_sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=SHND000020060614e26e00003&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=UZREPE0020060613e26e001gt&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=SHND000020060616e26g00003&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: Rudaki District is coded because it is the start of the road. I found the road by following it on GeoJSON. P501 turns into P513 and P514 but they are a part of the same road as outlined by the Reconnecting Asia map.

title: Chinese Government provided a RMB 60 million grant for the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID#39989)
description:
As part of a set of high-level agreements signed at the June 15, 2006 meeting of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO), the Chinese Government offered a RMB 60 million grant for the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project (see the cited resource:"China signs Tajik loan deals"). This project was also supported by a $281.1 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan from the Export-Import Bank of China (see Project ID#39989).

Earlier, in March 2006, China and Tajikistan had signed a Memorandum of Understanding that stated the terms of preferential credits issuance for promotion of economic and social development of SCO members. One of the financing projects identified was this road project.China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on July 11, 2006. The construction period was planned to be 38 months. The highway was commissioned in 2010, but work continued on the Shahristan tunnel. The project was wholly completed on October 27, 2012, with an opening ceremony for the Shahristan tunnel that was attended by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. 

The purpose of this project — also known as the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project — was to reconstruct the 354 km highway connecting Dushanbe with Khujand, the center of the northern province, and the town of Chanak on the border with Uzbekistan. The project also involved the construction of the 5253-meter Shahristan tunnel (at a cost of $88,424), the 1047-meter Dusti tunnel, the Maikhura tunnel, 39 big and small bridges, and 6 km of avalanche defenses. More detailed locational information is available at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbe-chanak-highway-including-shahristan-and-dusty-tunnels-rehabilitation/d0fdfa30-2790-41ab-8462-fb056c335c52/.

The project reportedly reduced driving times from 12 hours to 4 hours and the Shahristan tunnel was reportedly the longest tunnel in Central Asia when it completed, according to China Global Television Network. To help repay the loan and cover the costs of maintaining the road, the Tajik Government made the highway a toll road in 2010 and allowed the private company Innovative Road Solutions to collected tolls . 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is реабилитацию автомобильной дороги «Душанбе – Чанак». The Chinese project title is 塔乌（乌兹别克斯坦）公路.

The purpose of this project — also known as the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project — was to reconstruct the 354 km highway connecting Dushanbe with Khujand, the center of the northern province, and the town of Chanak on the border with Uzbekistan. The project also involved the construction of the 5253-meter Shahristan tunnel (at a cost of $88,424), the 1047-meter Dusti tunnel, the Maikhura tunnel, 39 big and small bridges, and 6 km of avalanche defenses. More detailed locational information is available at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbe-chanak-highway-including-shahristan-and-dusty-tunnels-rehabilitation/d0fdfa30-2790-41ab-8462-fb056c335c52/.

The project reportedly reduced driving times from 12 hours to 4 hours and the Shahristan tunnel was reportedly the longest tunnel in Central Asia when it completed, according to China Global Television Network. To help repay the loan and cover the costs of maintaining the road, the Tajik Government made the highway a toll road in 2010 and allowed the private company Innovative Road Solutions to collected tolls . 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is реабилитацию автомобильной дороги «Душанбе – Чанак». The Chinese project title is 塔乌（乌兹别克斯坦）公路.

title: Chinese Government provided a RMB 60 million grant for the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID#39989)
description:
As part of a set of high-level agreements signed at the June 15, 2006 meeting of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO), the Chinese Government offered a RMB 60 million grant for the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project (see the cited resource:"China signs Tajik loan deals"). This project was also supported by a $281.1 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan from the Export-Import Bank of China (see Project ID#39989).

Earlier, in March 2006, China and Tajikistan had signed a Memorandum of Understanding that stated the terms of preferential credits issuance for promotion of economic and social development of SCO members. One of the financing projects identified was this road project.China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on July 11, 2006. The construction period was planned to be 38 months. The highway was commissioned in 2010, but work continued on the Shahristan tunnel. The project was wholly completed on October 27, 2012, with an opening ceremony for the Shahristan tunnel that was attended by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. 

The purpose of this project — also known as the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project — was to reconstruct the 354 km highway connecting Dushanbe with Khujand, the center of the northern province, and the town of Chanak on the border with Uzbekistan. The project also involved the construction of the 5253-meter Shahristan tunnel (at a cost of $88,424), the 1047-meter Dusti tunnel, the Maikhura tunnel, 39 big and small bridges, and 6 km of avalanche defenses. More detailed locational information is available at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbe-chanak-highway-including-shahristan-and-dusty-tunnels-rehabilitation/d0fdfa30-2790-41ab-8462-fb056c335c52/.

The project reportedly reduced driving times from 12 hours to 4 hours and the Shahristan tunnel was reportedly the longest tunnel in Central Asia when it completed, according to China Global Television Network. To help repay the loan and cover the costs of maintaining the road, the Tajik Government made the highway a toll road in 2010 and allowed the private company Innovative Road Solutions to collected tolls . 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is реабилитацию автомобильной дороги «Душанбе – Чанак». The Chinese project title is 塔乌（乌兹别克斯坦）公路.

title: China provides an RMB 260 million grant for the Shar Shar (Ozodi) Tunnel Construction Project (Linked to Project IDs #53615, #72465)
description:
In 2006, the Chinese Government provided RMB 260 million in grant funding to support the Shar Shar (Ozodi) Tunnel Construction Project. Previously, in July 2005, China and Tajikistan reached an agreement for providing assistance for the construction of the Shar Shar (Ozodi) Tunnel. 

China Railway No.5 Engineering Group, a subsidiary of China Railway Engineering Corporation (CREC), was the contractor responsible for project implementation. CCCC Highway Consultants Co., Ltd. undertook preliminary design of the project. Xinjiang Highway Engineering Supervision Center was responsible for supervision of construction. The groundbreaking ceremony was held on October 20, 2006. The construction was scheduled to be completed in 34 months (see "Update: Construction of Shar-Shar tunnel in Khatlon officially begins"). The project was completed on August 8, 2009. A grand opening ceremony was held on August 30. In November 2010, the project won the China Construction Engineering Luban Prize.

The Shar-Shar Tunnel Project (alternatively: Sharshar) included a main tunnel with a total length of 2.23 km and a 4.91 km connection line (3.4 km for the northern connection line, 1.5 km for the southern connection line) and a 169-meter-long bridge in a mountainous and hilly area. This project aimed to promote general economic development. It also hoped to improve traffic conditions in Tajikistan, as well as strengthen business and logistics links between China and Tajikistan. Upon completion, the tunnel was to reportedly reduce the travel time from Dushanbe to Dangara, President Emomali Rahmon's hometown, by 40 minutes. 

This tunnel was located 80 km south of the capital city of Dushanbe, near the city of Kulyab in the Dangara District of Khatlon Region. It is on the Dushanbe-Vahdat-Dangara highway and was built under Shar-Shar mountain pass. More detailed locational information can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/ozodi-tunnel-construction/4c72ae7b-1c6b-4466-91b7-3092ba7ee8e4/.

This project is linked to ID#53615, which covers a Chinese Government grant to repair a 6 km access road to the Shar-Shar Tunnel, and #72465, a follow up grant in 2007.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 沙尔—沙尔隧道. The Russian project title is Ремонт подходных путей к тоннелю Озоди (Шар-Шар). The project is also known as the "Shahr-Shahr Tunnel and the North-South Link Project" (see "援塔吉克斯坦沙尔-沙尔隧道和南北连接线项目竣工典礼隆重举行"). The Shar-Shar tunnel was renamed the Ozodi (in English: Liberty) tunnel in 2014 (see "Chormaghzak Tunnel renamed Khatlon Tunnel and Shar-Shar Tunnel renamed Ozodi Tunnel"). 

The Government of Tajikistan’s Aid Information Management System (AIMS) identifies $41,664,633 as the amount of grant funding provided by the Chinese Government. This project is identified by identification number TJK/102014 in the AIMS, and its title in the AIMS is 'Construction of auto-tunnel Shar-shar'' (see "May 2018 Flat Export from Tajikistan AIMS China Specific Projects" resource). However, we chose to code the RMB 260 million estimate provided by the China’s Embassy in Tajikistan since the Chinese Government typically denominates its grant agreements in RMB and in a Speech of the Chancellery of the Adviser for Trade and Economic Issues of the PRC, the grant was denominated in RMB.

title: China to provide 70 million RMB technical assistance to Tajikistan
description: In 2017, China committed to grant technical facilities worth 70 million RMB to Tajikistan to strengthen its capacity of emergency response. Committee of Emergency Situations and Civil Defense secured automobiles, munitions, and special technical equipment from China through an agreement under the United Nations Development Programme. More than 100,000 people live in danger areas in Tajikistan, and 27 people have died in natural disasters in the first half of 2017. As of July, 2017, 284 areas in Tajikistan were considered dangerous for human habitation. Along with the project, the Committee will also receive $500,000 grant from Japan and $460,000 from Russia.
sources: https://www.osce.org/programme-office-in-dushanbe/386510?download=true, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.xinhuanet.com//english/2017-07/21/c_136460396.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: The purpose of this project is to increase Tajikistan's emergency preparedness. It is a capacity building project that will affect the entire country.

title: Chinese Government provides food aid worth RMB 15 million to Tajikistan
description: On March 12, 2003, as part of a humanitarian relief package, China sent Tajikistan RMB 15 million worth of food aid. The food aid was intended to help alleviate Tajikistan's food issues, as the country is not self-sufficient in food production. The food aid included 2,340 tons of sugar, 1,200 tons of rice, and 320 tons of soybean. STAFF_NOTE: The May 2018 Flat Export from Tajikistan AIMS reported that the food aid was worth USD 1,812,000. This is approximately equal to RMB 15 million. The AIMS project ID is TJK/042050. The CNY amount was coded because it came from a Chinese official source from Chinese Embassy's Economic and Commercial office. The AIMS project ID is TJK/042050. This project is not to be confused with humanitarian aid provided by China in November 2002 (captured in project ID#72328).
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=afpr000020030313dz3d0005r&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://tj.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/jmxw/200305/20030500093181.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/rl546mymjz3f15f/May%202018%20Flat%20Export%20from%20Tajikistan%20AIMS%20China%20Specific%20Projects.xlsx?dl=0, Other
GEO_notes: China gave Tajikistan a large donation of food because it is not self-sufficient. There was no more information on where the food went to so it was coded up to country level.

title: China grants RMB 10 million emergency humanitarian relief to Tajikistan
description: On July 23, 2015, Chinese Foreign Minister of China Wang Yi pledged to provide emergency humanitarian relief to Tajikistan during the meeting with his Tajik counterpart Sirojiddin Aslov. Constant high temperature since July caused glaciers to melt, leading to severe landslides in Tajikistan and causing serious casualties. On August 5, the Department of Foreign Assistance of MOFCOM delivered Tajikistan RMB10 million relief.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=CEASEN0020150724eb7o000jk&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://sydney.chineseconsulate.org/chn//zgxw/t1283525.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://english.mofcom.gov.cn/article/newsrelease/significantnews/201508/20150801075452.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: The mudslides that the emergency aid was addressing occurred across the country. There was no more information on granular location so it was coded up to country level.

title: China Grants $6M to Fight Poverty in Tajikistan
description: Summary: In 2004, China donated nearly 6 million dollars to neighboring Tajikistan to help fight poverty in the Central Asian nation. Mountainous Tajikistan has a 520-kilometer (325-mile) border with its huge eastern neighbor. The two countries inaugurated their first border crossing for vehicles, goods and people in May.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCCA00020040726e07q000xe&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=AFPR000020040726e07q007nb&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China Eximbank provides $49 million preferential buyer’s credit for First Stage of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID#53750, #40440)
description:
On August 18, 2009, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and the Export-Import Bank of China signed a $49,000,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan for the First Stage of the Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project. The loan had a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period of 5 years, and an interest rate of 2%. 

The total project cost was $51,578,000, including a $2,578,000 contribution from the Government of Tajikistan. China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on August 30, 2009 after a grand commencement ceremony held on the same day and the project was completed (after passing final inspection) on October 30, 2013. 

This project supported the reconstruction of a 57.8 km road segment along the 147.64 km Dushanbe-Vahdat-Dangara section of the Dushanbe-Kulma highway (which is also known as the Tajikistan-China highway). It also involved the construction of new sections of road to bypass settlements and bridges. More detailed locational information can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbekulma-road-dushanbe-dangara-section-phase-2/9d21c81e-6931-4df6-9dd4-650c86518ecb/.

STAFF_NOTE: This project is linked to the China Eximbank-financed Second Stage and China Eximbank-financed Third Stage of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (see Project ID#53750, #40440). China Eximbank reportedly provided $243.4 million of debt financing in total for all three stages of Phase 1. The Russian project title for Stage 1 of Phase 1 is Реконструкция 1-го этапа 1 фазы автодороги Душанбе-Кульма (Таджикистан - граница Китая) на участке «Душанбе-Дангара». The Chinese project title is 塔中公路一期(杜尚别—丹卡拉段)道路修复改造项目.

title: China Eximbank provides $49 million preferential buyer’s credit for First Stage of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID#53750, #40440)
description:
On August 18, 2009, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and the Export-Import Bank of China signed a $49,000,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan for the First Stage of the Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project. The loan had a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period of 5 years, and an interest rate of 2%. 

The total project cost was $51,578,000, including a $2,578,000 contribution from the Government of Tajikistan. China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on August 30, 2009 after a grand commencement ceremony held on the same day and the project was completed (after passing final inspection) on October 30, 2013. 

This project supported the reconstruction of a 57.8 km road segment along the 147.64 km Dushanbe-Vahdat-Dangara section of the Dushanbe-Kulma highway (which is also known as the Tajikistan-China highway). It also involved the construction of new sections of road to bypass settlements and bridges. More detailed locational information can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbekulma-road-dushanbe-dangara-section-phase-2/9d21c81e-6931-4df6-9dd4-650c86518ecb/.

STAFF_NOTE: This project is linked to the China Eximbank-financed Second Stage and China Eximbank-financed Third Stage of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (see Project ID#53750, #40440). China Eximbank reportedly provided $243.4 million of debt financing in total for all three stages of Phase 1. The Russian project title for Stage 1 of Phase 1 is Реконструкция 1-го этапа 1 фазы автодороги Душанбе-Кульма (Таджикистан - граница Китая) на участке «Душанбе-Дангара». The Chinese project title is 塔中公路一期(杜尚别—丹卡拉段)道路修复改造项目.

title: China grants 79 million RMB to Tajikistan for the Shar Shar (Ozodi) Tunnel Construction Project (Linked with projects #40406, #53615)
description:
In 2007, the Chinese Government provided RMB 79 million in grant funding to support the Shar Shar (Ozodi) Tunnel Construction Project. Previously, in July 2005, China and Tajikistan reached an agreement for providing assistance for the construction of the Shar Shar (Ozodi) Tunnel. This grant funding was not only used for direct tunnel construction but for the provision of buses,  Mobile inspection and observation complex, radiotechnics and other systems, though the specific breakdown is unknown.

China Railway No.5 Engineering Group, a subsidiary of China Railway Engineering Corporation (CREC), was the contractor responsible for project implementation. CCCC Highway Consultants Co., Ltd. undertook preliminary design of the project. Xinjiang Highway Engineering Supervision Center was responsible for supervision of construction. The groundbreaking ceremony was held on October 20, 2006. The construction was scheduled to be completed in 34 months (see "Update: Construction of Shar-Shar tunnel in Khatlon officially begins"). The project was completed on August 8, 2009. A grand opening ceremony was held on August 30. In November 2010, the project won the China Construction Engineering Luban Prize.

The Shar-Shar Tunnel Project (alternatively: Sharshar) included a main tunnel with a total length of 2.23 km and a 4.91 km connection line (3.4 km for the northern connection line, 1.5 km for the southern connection line) and a 169-meter-long bridge in a mountainous and hilly area. This project aimed to promote general economic development. It also hoped to improve traffic conditions in Tajikistan, as well as strengthen business and logistics links between China and Tajikistan. Upon completion, the tunnel was to reportedly reduce the travel time from Dushanbe to Dangara, President Emomali Rahmon's hometown, by 40 minutes. 

This tunnel was located 80 km south of the capital city of Dushanbe, near the city of Kulyab in the Dangara District of Khatlon Region. It is on the Dushanbe-Vahdat-Dangara highway and was built under Shar-Shar mountain pass. More detailed locational information can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/ozodi-tunnel-construction/4c72ae7b-1c6b-4466-91b7-3092ba7ee8e4/.

This project is linked to ID#53615, which covers a Chinese Government grant to repair a 6 km access road to the Shar-Shar Tunnel, and #40406, an earlier donation for the same project

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 沙尔—沙尔隧道. The Russian project title is Ремонт подходных путей к тоннелю Озоди (Шар-Шар). The project is also known as the "Shahr-Shahr Tunnel and the North-South Link Project" (see "援塔吉克斯坦沙尔-沙尔隧道和南北连接线项目竣工典礼隆重举行"). The Shar-Shar tunnel was renamed the Ozodi (in English: Liberty) tunnel in 2014 (see "Chormaghzak Tunnel renamed Khatlon Tunnel and Shar-Shar Tunnel renamed Ozodi Tunnel"). 

The Government of Tajikistan’s Aid Information Management System (AIMS) identifies $41,664,633 as the amount of grant funding provided by the Chinese Government. This project is identified by identification number TJK/102014 in the AIMS, and its title in the AIMS is 'Construction of auto-tunnel Shar-shar'' (see "May 2018 Flat Export from Tajikistan AIMS China Specific Projects" resource). However, we chose to code the RMB 260 million estimate provided by the China’s Embassy in Tajikistan since the Chinese Government typically denominates its grant agreements in RMB and in a Speech of the Chancellery of the Adviser for Trade and Economic Issues of the PRC, the grant was denominated in RMB.

title: Chinese Government provides an RMB 200 million grant to Tajikistan in ETCA (Linked to Project ID#40482, #69997, #40479, #72802)
description: On May 20, 2013, as a part of an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), China agreed to provide Tajikistan a grant of RMB 200 million, as one of seven agreements signed between China and Tajikistan during the official meetings and negotiations between Xi Jinping and President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon, according to Amonatbonk. The grant money comes with 'no strings attatched,' or no stipulation on usage. The other agreements signed on May 20, 2013 were: a collection of loans totaling USD 20 million to Amonatbonk (captured in project ID#72802 ), a collection of loans totaling 33 million RMB to Amonatbonk (captured in project ID#69997), an agreement for the reconstruction of Regar Substation (captured in project ID#40482), a loan to Zijin Mining for investment into the Zeravshan Gold Mine (captured in project ID#40479), a technical cooperation agreement, a fruit inspection protocol, and a sports cooperation agreement.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=ASIPLU0020130520e95k0005p&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.tj/en/news/tajikistan/politics/20130520/china-reportedly-expected-allot-200-million-yuan-no-strings-tajikistan, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.amonatbonk.tj/en/about/news/3184/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://jamestown.org/program/china-as-tajikistans-lender-of-last-resort/, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)
GEO_notes: China gave Tajikistan a grant with no restrictions. There was no information about where it went to.

title: China sponsored an electronic classroom of the Tajik State Institute of Languages
description: On September 24, 2016, Yue Bin, Ambassador of Tajikistan, attended the opening ceremony of the electric classroom of theTajik State Institute of Languages sponsored by the Chinese Embassy in Beijing. The president of the National Language University of Raja Buzoda, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Ministry of Tajikistan, and representatives of the Ministry of Education and more than 300 students and teachers attended the event.
sources: http://tj.chineseembassy.org/chn/xwdt/t1400272.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: China sponsored the electric classroom of theTajik State Institute of Languages. This university is located in the city of Dushanbe so I coded Rudaki District.

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 929.9 million government concessional loan for Phase 2 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project (Linked to Project ID #54106, #71101, #71137)
description:
On July 4, 2009, the Export-Import Bank of China and China Development Bank (CDB) provided a $30 million USD loan for Phase 1 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project. According to Trend News Agency, the project's financing was on a 50-50 basis by the two Chinese banks to Ministry of Energy and Industry of Tajikistan. Other detailed terms of this loan are unknown. Project ID#54106 only captures the $15 million USD from China Eximbank. China Development Bank's contribution was captured in project ID#71101. Other detailed terms of this loan are unknown.

Then, in 2014, the Export-Import Bank of China provided two loans — an RMB 929,977,078 government concessional loan (GCL) (captured in project ID#46211) and a $178,969,220 USD preferential buyer’s credit loan (PBC) (captured in project ID#71137) for Phase 2 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project (for the GCL loan amount, see pg. 87 of "Program Appraisal Document on a Proposed Grant..."; for the PBC loan amount, see "Information on existing state investment projects"). Both of these loans were ratified by the Tajik Parliament on January 14, 2015. The GCL loan was contracted with the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and it carried the following terms: 25 year maturity, 11 year grace period, and 1.5% interest rate (see "РАМОЧНОЕ СОГЛАШЕНИЕ между Правительством Китайской Народной Республики и Правительством Республики Таджикистан о предоставлении Китайской Народной Республикой Республике Таджикистан льготного кредита"). The PBC loan has a 20 year maturity, 9 year grace period, and 2% interest rate (see "List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018").

The Government of Tajikistan contributed $17,443,400 USD. In total, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan contracted $331,058,220 USD of China Eximbank debt for Phase 2 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project. The Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from the GCL and the PBC loan to on-lend to Open Joint Stock Holding Company (OHSHC) “Barqi Tojik”. OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy.

The subsidiary GCL loan agreement (#TАJ 2014-028-2) was signed between Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” on December 18, 2014. It carried an interest rate of 5% and a maturity of 25 years. Its final maturity date was set to August 21, 2039. The subsidiary PBC loan agreement (#TАJ 2014-028-1) was also signed between Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” on December 18, 2014 and it carried an interest rate of 5% and a maturity of 20 years. Its final maturity date was set to June 21, 2034.

Dushanbe 2 is a combined heat and power plant (CHP) — also known as the Dushanbe-2 Thermal Power Plant (TPS-2) — that provides heat and electricity for the residents of Dushanbe. It only operates in the winter. The 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project required two phases. Phase 1 (mainly constructed between 2012-2014) installed a capacity of 100 MW, while Phase 2 (constructed between 2014-2016) installed an additional capacity of 300 MW. TBEA was the contractor responsible for implementation of both phases. CHP-2 was to be fueled by coal, with the potential to switch to gas. According to State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission of the State Council, Inner Mongolia Electric Power Survey and Design Institute Co., Ltd. was the project designer for Phase 2. According to PowerChina, Hydro Electric Power System Engineering Company was also involved in the undertaking of Phase 2 of the project.

The first phase was scheduled to be completed and put into production before the celebration of the 20th anniversary of Tajik independence in 2011 (September 9th), and the second phase was scheduled to be completed in 2013. Phase 1 of the project began on September 8, 2009 and was put into operation on November 10, 2014. Phase 2 of the project began on May 14, 2015 and was completed on December 8, 2016.

According to President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon as relayed by TBEA, the plant generates 9.6 million kWh power per day and 235 trillion Kcal heat, and provided nearly 700 stable jobs to Tajiks. 150 Tajikistan technicians went to China for training, and about 100 Tajikistan operators mastered professional know-how under the guidance of Chinese experts. According to Xinhua, the completed station met 60 percent of the power demand and enabled the restart of central heating for more than 700,000 Dushanbe residents after 15 years of suspension. The completion of the Dushanbe-2 thermal power station was also declared to be the solution to Tajikistan's long-existing issue of power shortages in winter.

This power plant is located in Dushanbe. Its exact locational coordinates are available at http://globalenergyobservatory.org/geoid/41775.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Душанбинская ТЭЦ-2. The $30 million loan from China Eximbank and China Development Bank may not have covered the full cost of Phase 1 of the project. In the Government of Tajikistan’s Aid Information Management System (AIMS), the project is referred to as "Project of construction of second in succession construction of 'TPS-2' in Dushanbe."

Some sources suggest that major delays took place after Tajikistan contracted this loan on July 4, 2009. The ceremony for the beginning of the project was clearly on September 8, 2009, but it seems project construction did not begin in earnest until 2012, when TBEA agreed to “front” $178 million for the construction of Phase 1 by borrowing directly from China Eximbank, and, in turn, the Tajik government agreed to grant TBEA exclusive rights to explore and develop gold deposits at the Eastern Duoba mine and the Upper Kumarg mine (until TBEA could recoup its investment). The Tajik government also reportedly agreed to give TBEA the rights to further mining deposits (at an unidentified location) if the profit made from the gold deposits did not cover the cost of building the power plant.

According to Kazakhstan Newsline, Tajikistan also issued a license to TBEA for the development of coal mines (see "Chinese TBEA company says Dushanbe is ready to provide its gold mines"). Another media source, Central Asia News, said that the mineral resources were to be used to compensate the costs of the company for construction of the Dushanbe-2 in the amount of $178 million USD. It also reported that the proven reserves of 3 gold mines was to be estimated 51.7 tons of gold (see "China’s TBEA may obtain license for development of another mine in Tajikistan"). Another media source, Asia-Plus reported that the license for development of the Upper Kumargh gold deposit was granted to TBEA in 2018. It also reported that in 2013, the Tajik Government gave TBEA licenses for exploration operations at both these deposits until 2017, while also exempting TBEA from customs duties and value added tax on the import of equipment (see "China's TBEA granted licenses for development of two gold deposits in Tajikistan").

It is also important to note that the Economic and Commercial Office of the Chinese Embassy reported in 2009 that TBEA was to receive mining rights in return for the project, before this exchange took place. "The Full Story Behind China's Gold Mine-Power Plant Swap in Tajikistan" article from the Diplomat is a particularly helpful source for information on this "resource-for-infrastructure" deal.

title: Chinese Government grants RMB 60 million for feasibility study of the construction of a school in Dangara
description: In 2009, the Chinese Government and the Government of Tajikistan signed a technical economic agreement for China to provide grant aid of RMB 60 million to conduct a feasibility study on the construction of a school in Dangara District, Khatlon Province (see pg.79 of 'Development Partner Profiles 2014'). STAFF_NOTE: The agreement for this grant is called 'Technical Economic Agreement for feasibility study on the project of construction of a school in Dangara district in Khatlon province' by the Government of Tajikistan's AIMS system, project ID TJK/102179. Additionally, the RMB 60 million was used instead of $8,788,633 USD because Chinese Government grants tend to distribute RMB grants.
sources: https://www.dropbox.com/s/rl546mymjz3f15f/May%202018%20Flat%20Export%20from%20Tajikistan%20AIMS%20China%20Specific%20Projects.xlsx?dl=0 , Other; https://uceec09b265043133ca8d4b53bdb.previews.dropboxusercontent.com/nativeprint?file=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.dropbox.com%2Fs%2Fj174ru3dvw3sl4k%2F2016%2520Development%2520Partners%2520Profiles%2520From%2520State%2520Committee%2520on%2520Investments%2520and%2520State%2520Property%2520Management.pdf%3Fdisable_range%3D1%26from_native_print%3D1%26preview%3D1, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://untj.org/dcc/files/2014-2015/Strategic-Framework/dpp_2014_en.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
GEO_notes: A feasibility study for a school in Danghara District was conducted.
Christian Notes: good. Feasibility study only, but exchange of large amt of funds. Err on side of coding this

title: China Granted $19,000 Worth of Aid to Tajik Emergency Ministry
description: Summary: On September 20, 2004, Chinese ambassador to Tajikistan, Wu Hongbin, presented humanitarian aid to the Tajik Ministry of Emergency Situations. The humanitarian aid consisted of tents and children's clothing. The total value of the aid is 19,000 dollars. Officials from the Tajik Ministry of Emergency Situations expressed their gratitude to embassy officials for this no-strings aid. The aid provided would be used in the event of natural disasters.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=ASIPLU0020041006e09k0008g&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCCA00020040921e09l001p5&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

GEO_notes: The tents and children's clothing were given to the Tajik Ministry of Emergency Situations, which is located in Dushanbe. However, this aid is to be used for future situations so I coded up to country level.

title: China grants Tajikistan 10 buses and 25 tractors
description: Stipulated under earlier agreements, China granted Tajikistan 10 buses and 25 tractors. No further information regarding the value of the equipment was located.

GEO_notes: China gave Tajikistan vehicles. Even though the location says Dushanbe, I could find no source that said it was given to the city so I coded up to country level as no more granular information was available.

title: Chinese Government provides $2 million grant for the Reconstruction of the Shirgovad Section of the Dushanbe-Kulma Highway
description:
On October 23, 2017, an exchange of letters between China and Tajikistan was signed that stipulated that China would help Tajikistan repair roads. According to the Tajik Ministry of Transport, the Chinese Government provided a grant of $2 million for the Reconstruction of the Shirgovad Section of the Dushanbe-Kulma Highway Project. The project aimed to restore the Shirgovad section, in the Darvaz Distrct, of the Dushanbe-Kulma Highway that had been destroyed by a flood. China Road and Bridge Construction Corporation (China Road) was the contractor. The project commenced in December 2017 and was completed in April 2018. 1.1 km of the Dushanbe-Kulma highway was restored in the project.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Восстановление участка 347 км автодороги Душанбе-Кульма (участок Ширговад Дарвазского района). The Tajik project title is Барқарорсозии қитъаи 347 км р/а Душанбе-Кулма (мавзеи Ширговади н.Дарвоз). Additionally, while the sources do not explicitly state so, this was clearly done in response to the July 2017 flooding that damaged and destroyed roadways in the Darvaz District.
sources: https://mintrans.tj/ru/road-facilities/implimented, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://mintrans.tj/tg/road-facilities/projects/barkarorsozii-kitai-347-km-ra-dushanbe-kulma-mavzei-shirgovadi-ndarvoz, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://mintrans.tj/ru/road-facilities/projects/vosstanovlenie-uchastka-347-km-avtodorogi-dushanbe-kulma-uchastok-shirgovad, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://asiaplustj.info/ru/news/tajikistan/power/20190817/mintrans-o-doroge-dushanbe-horog-prosim-proyavit-terpenie, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://avesta.tj/2017/07/24/dvizhenie-avtotransporta-po-avtodoroge-dushanbe-kulyab-horog-vosstanovleno/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://tj.chineseembassy.org/chn/sbgx/t1503906.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
location_details: The project aims to restore the Shirgovad section, in the Darvaz Distrct, of the Dushanbe-Kulma Highway that had been destroyed by a flood.
GEO_notes: China paid for the reconstruction of the Shirgovad Section of the Dushanbe-Kulma Highway Project. This section is located in Darvoz District, which is also spelled as Darvaz District. I coded this district using QGIS.

title: China Embassy funded the Women's Sewing Training and Production Center in Dushanbe (Linked to Project ID#53594, #54043, #53591)
description:
On January 8, 2016, Yue Bin, Ambassador of Tajikistan, attended the inauguration ceremony of the Women's Sewing Training Production Center in Sino District, Dushanbe (Chinese location name: 杜尚别市西诺区), sponsored by the Chinese Embassy. It is believed that the establishment of the training production center will definitely play a positive role in further promoting local women's employment and improving their living standards, and at the same time writing a new chapter for the friendship between the people of Tazhong.

Chinese Embassy also funded other differenct Women’s Sewing Training and Production Center in Tajikistan. Project ID#53594 captured the sewing center in Danghara. Project ID#54043 captured the sewing center in Maslozhelkomupo District, Dushanbe. Project ID#53591 captured the sewing center in Vakhsh District, Khatlon.
sources: http://tj.chineseembassy.org/chn/xwdt/t1330435.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.mfa.gov.cn/chn//pds/gjhdq/gj/yz/1206_29/1206x2/t1330436.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: The Women's Sewing Training Production Center was funded by China. This specific Center is located in Sino District, Dushanbe.

title: China grants food, tents and sheets to Tajikistan for Harsh Winter Relief
description: In April 2012, the government of China sent Tajikistan a humanitarian aid package consisting of 220 tons of rice, 120 tons of vegetable oil, tents, and sheets. It is unclear which part of the Chinese government provided the funding, and the financial value of the project is unclear. STAFF_NOTE: This project should not be confused with project #57839, the 2011 natural disaster response from China to Tajikistan. The 2012 aid package primarily seeks to address the impact of an unusually cold winter, while the 2011 aid package primarily seeks to address a flood.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCCA00020120416e84g000m9&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=CEASEN0020120417e84h000b7&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dropbox.com/s/rl546mymjz3f15f/May%202018%20Flat%20Export%20from%20Tajikistan%20AIMS%20China%20Specific%20Projects.xlsx?dl=0, Other
factiva_sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCCA00020120416e84g000m9&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=CEASEN0020120417e84h000b7&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: There was no information on where the aid for the harsh winter was sent in Tajikistan. The entire country faced a harsh winter so it was coded up to country level.

title: Chinese Embassy funded Danghara Women’s Sewing Training and Production Center (Linked to project ID#54043, #53587, #53591, #71883, #71881)
description:
The Chinese Embassy to Tajikistan funded Danghara Women’s Sewing Training and Production Center, located in the hometown of President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. The opening ceremony of center was held on January 11, 2017. The center was intended to improve the well-being of the Tajik people and promote the women's employment, according to the embassy. The value of the donated sewing center is unknown. 

Chinese Embassy also funded other differenct Women’s Sewing Training and Production Center in Tajikistan. Project ID#54043 captured the sewing center in Maslozhelkomupo District, Dushanbe. Project ID#53591 captured the sewing center in Vakhsh District, Khatlon. Project ID#53587 captured the sewing center in Sino District, Dushanbe. Project ID#71883 captured the sewing center named "Gurdaston" in Dushanbe. Project ID#71881 captured the sewing center in the Dzhami District, Khatlon. 

STAFF_NOTE: "Year uncertain" was checked because it is not confirmed that this donation was committed in 2017. "Dangara" is also used in the name of the center.
sources: http://tj.chineseembassy.org/chn/xwdt/t1429681.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: China founded the Danghara Women’s Sewing Training and Production Center. It is located in Danghara District.

title: Agricultural Bank of China loans RMB 200 million to Zhongtai (Dangara) New Silk Road Textile Industry Company for the Agricultural and Textile Industrial Park Project (Linked to Project ID#46222, #54353)
description:
On September 29, 2017, the Agricultural Bank of China, Xinjiang Corps Branch, "successfully handled" a loan of RMB 200 million for Agricultural and Textile Industrial Park Project in Tajikistan. The loan was intended to support the construction of the project in Tajikistan by the Xinjiang Production and Construction Corps (see "农行兵团分行为塔吉克斯坦农业产业园项目提供亿元资金支持"). 

The Agricultural and Textile Industrial Park project was reportedly the largest agricultural and textile investment project in Tajikistan since its independence in 1991 (see pg.64 of "2018 Corporate Social Responsibility Report"). The project included 200,000 mu of cotton agricultural park and 150,000 spinning spindles. The first phase of 150,000 mu of cotton was to be sown in 2015, and the spinning project was to be completed and put into operation in 2016.  After the project is completed, the industrial park was expected to be able to produce 80,000 tons of seed cotton, 32,000 tons of lint, 24,000 tons of cotton yarn, 91.5 million meters of cotton cloth, annual sales revenue of RMB 1.525 billion, and a profit of RMB 250 million, improving the welfare of its workers and driving industrial and agricultural development in Tajikistan. 

For a $118 million USD loan from the Export-Import Bank of China for the industrial park, see linked project ID#46222. For a RMB 1.1 billion investment by three Chinese companies in the industrial park, please see linked project ID#54353.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 为塔吉克斯坦农业产业园 or 中泰新丝路塔吉克斯坦农业纺织产业园. The groundbreaking ceremony of the entire Agricultural and Textile Project was held on December 19, 2014. The project was commissioned and the zone started operation on August 31, 2016. Thus, this loan could not be for the first phase construction. It is possible, if not likely, they were intended for the second or third phases (See " 驻塔吉克斯坦大使岳斌与塔总统共同出席中资企业在塔投资项目投产仪式").
sources: http://www.bhi.com.cn/ydyl/gwdt/44012.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.apfc-cwto.org/newsitem/277071994, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://info.texnet.com.cn/detail-602090.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://m.sinotex.cn/read.asp?id=147153, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.china.org.cn/business/2019-04/25/content_74719020.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.abchina.com/en/AboutUs/csr-report/201904/P020190925352626015065.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://news.cctv.com/2018/05/31/ARTIx8kpqfM0z0E5XB34kZBu180531.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://world.people.com.cn/n/2014/1221/c157278-26246325.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.abchina.com/cn/branch/xj/news/201510/t20151027_782758.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://tj.china-embassy.org/chn/dszl/dshd/t1393421.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://tj.china-embassy.org/chn/dszl/dshd/t1610438.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
location_details: This project involved the construction of an agricultural industrial park and a large cotton processing and textile producing enterprise in Dangara District within Tajikistan's Khatlon Province.
GEO_notes: The Agricultural and Textile Industrial Park Project was built with a loan from China. It is located in Danghara District.

title: China Eximbank provides $36.9 million preferential buyer’s credit for the Upgrade of the Vahdat-Yavan Section of the Dushanbe-Kurgantube Railway Project (Linked to Project ID#40489)
description:
On November 7, 2014, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed two loan agreements with the Export-Import Bank of China for the Upgrade of the Vahdat-Yavan Section of the Dushanbe-Kurgantube Railway Project: a RMB-denominated government concessional loan (GCL) provided on highly concessional terms (20 year maturity, 11 year grace period, and 1.5% interest rate) and a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan on highly concessional terms (2% interest, 20 year maturity, 9 year grace period), each with a bank service fee of 0.2% and a reservation fee of 0.2%).

On August 13, 2013, State Unitary Enterprise “Rohi Ohani Tojikiston” had signed a contract for the survey, design and construction of tunnels and bridges of the new Dushanbe-Kurgan-Tyube railway, Vahdat-Yavan section for $59,993,900 USD. The Government of Tajikistan approved this deal on August 28, 2013, and ordered the Ministry of Finance to attract a soft loan from China Eximbank. The total cost of the project was approximately $71.993 million USD. The loans from the Export-Import Bank of China were valued at $68,992,970 USD. Tajikistan contributed $2,999,700 USD through State Unitary Enterprise "Rohi Ohani Tojikiston” (see "Information on existing state investment projects" and "Строительство мостов и тоннелей на железной дороги Душанбе-Кургантюбе, участок Вахдат-Яван" from the Ministry of Transport of the Republic of Tajikistan).

The face value of the GCL loan was RMB 191.9 million. The face value of the PBC loan was $36.9 million USD (pg.5 of “Отчет о состоянии государственного долга на 2014 год”). These loans combined are roughly equal to the reported Eximbank contribution. The loans were ratified by the Tajik Parliament on January 14, 2015. Project ID#40489 records the GCL and Project ID#71443 records the PBC.

This project was to become the first railway project launched and completed under the framework of the "Silk Road Economic Belt" initiative, and was to become a hub of an international railway network connecting China, Tajikistan, Afghanistan, and Iran. China Railway 19th Bureau Group Co Ltd was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on May 15, 2015 and the project was completed on August 24, 2016.

This project involved the construction of construction of 5 bridges and 3 tunnels along the Vakhdat-Yavan section of the Dushanbe-Kurgantube railway. Additional locational details can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/vahdat-yavan-railway-construction/bde10173-33b5-4431-9ad2-19468648bcbd/.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Строительство железной дороги Душанбе-Курган-тюбе, участок Вахдат- Яван. Yavan is also spelled Yovon. Vahdat is also spelled Vakhdat.
sources: https://tj.sputniknews.ru/economy/20150114/1013930117.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.portali-huquqi.tj/publicadliya/view_qonunhoview.php?showdetail=&asosi_id=16734, Government Source (Donor/Recipient);
