http://minfin.tj/downloads/ochet%20vnesh%20dolg_2014.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.mintrans.tj/en/ground-transportation/projects/construction-bridges-and-tunnels-dushanbe-kurgantube-railway-vakhdat, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://asiaplustj.info/ru/news/tajikistan/power/20150114/201567, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://reconasia-production.s3.amazonaws.com/media/filer_public/16/df/16df9a08-2448-4952-ab7a-45ace5242df4/337_carec_presentation_2018.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://minfin.tj/downloads/otchet_2015.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.railwaygazette.com/infrastructure/inauguration-connects-tajik-rail-networks/43069.article, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://russian.news.cn/2016-11/16/c_135832146.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.mintrans.tj/ru/ground-transportation/projects/stroitelstvo-mostov-i-tonneley-na-zheleznoy-dorogi-dushanbe, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.adlia.tj/show_doc.fwx?rgn=119962, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/dushanbe-kurgantube-railway-vahdat-yavan-section-construction/bde10173-33b5-4431-9ad2-19468648bcbd/, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; https://www.dropbox.com/s/2ho5900a88zqnuv/Construction%20of%20bridges%20and%20tunnels%20on%20the%20Dushanbe-Kurgantyube%20railway%2C%20Vahdat-Yavan%20section%20_%20Ministry%20of%20Transport%20of%20the%20Republic%20of%20Tajikistan.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://globalriskinsights.com/2018/07/belt-and-road-initiative-increases-sovereign-debt-risks-in-tajikistan/, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://investcom.tj/en/investments/foreign-aid/184-current-projects.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
location_details: This project involved the construction of construction of 5 bridges and 3 tunnels along the Vakhdat-Yavan section of the Dushanbe-Kurgantube railway.
GEO_notes: Yovon District is coded in this row. It contains some of the construction of the section of the road. It is also spelled as Yavan.

title: China Friendship Foundation for Peace and Development (CFFPD) provides $300,000 USD for technical support for Tajikistan National University
description: On January 14, 2016, Ambassador Yue Bin of Tajikistan attended the handover ceremony of the multimedia audio-visual project of Tajikistan National University, which was built by the China Peace Development Foundation (PDP). At the ceremony, the China Friendship Foundation for Peace and Development (CFFPD) provided US$300,000 worth of technical assistance to Tajik National University. The modern audio-visual facilities established have created a good learning environment for Tajik students. The foundation is founded by the Chinese People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries, one of the three major foreign affairs organizations of China, and thus assumed to be an official agency.
sources: http://tj.chineseembassy.org/chn/xwdt/t1331809.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.asiaplus.tj/en/news/tajikistan/society/20170310/237470, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: The Tajik National University is located in the city of Dushanbe. I coded Rudaki District.

title: People's Bank of China loans $20 million to the State Savings Bank of Tajikistan (Linked to project ID#72549)
description: In September 2014, the State Savings Bank of Tajikistan, Amonatbok, and the People's Bank of China have negotiated a 20 million US concessional loan. The loan will be used for construction of the bank's new building and expansion of the bank's agricultural credit. The project's overall aim is to expand entrepreneurship and alleviate poverty in Tajikistan. The project is linked to another funding from CDB for the same construction project, which was captured in project ID#72549.
sources: http://en.people.cn/n/2014/0715/c90883-8755972.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.avesta.tj/eng/goverment/3758-amonatbonk-peoples-bank-of-china-negotiating-on-allocation-of-concessional-loan.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: The purpose of this project is to build a new bank in Dushanbe. This will allow the Bank to help more people in Tajikistan. I coded the district of Rudaki.

title: China Eximbank provides $12.54 million preferential buyer's credit for Safe City Project (Linked to Project ID#46215)
description:
On May 20, 2013, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed two loan agreements with the Export-Import Bank of China for the Safe City Project: a RMB-denominated government concessional loan (GCL) provided on highly concessional terms (20-year maturity, 11-year grace period, and 1.5% interest rate) and a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan on highly concessional terms (2% interest, 20-year maturity, 9-year grace period).

The precise face value of the GCL loan and the precise face value of the PBC loan are unknown. However, it is known that the GCL and PBC are jointly worth $20.9 million USD, and that 40% of the total debt financing from China Eximbank ($8.36 million) came from the RMB-denominated GCL and 60% of the total debt financing from China Eximbank ($12.54 million) came from the USD-denominated PBC (AidData learned this through correspondence with the IMF, see "Following Up" resource). Project ID#46215 records the GCL and project ID#71411 records the PBC.

The loans were ratified by the Tajik Parliament in June 2013 and were expected to be repaid with revenues from the traffic fines generated by this project. The total cost of the project was $22 million USD. In addition to the Chinese loans, the Government of Tajikistan contributed $1.1 million USD.

According to Ministry of Internal Affairs of the Republic of Tajikistan, the Safe City Project involved the installation of 855 CCTV cameras for round-the-clock monitoring of traffic and other movements at 75 crossroads, streets, and squares in the capital city of Dushanbe. The cameras were to record every offense committed by drivers, which would be stored and processed in a common database. Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd. was responsible for project implementation. Tajik Ministry of Internal Affairs was also responsible for the undertaking of the project.

The Safe City project and the control center were officially launched on October 31, 2013 by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. The Safe City Project was to be carried out in three stages; the second stage was expected to be finished in May 2014. The project was still on going as of December 2014. As of January 16, 2015, it had reportedly generated $4 million for the Tajik state budget via traffic fines. According to a Huawei report issued in February 2015, Huawei completed the project successfully.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Автоматическая система управления транспорта в городе Душанбе (Безопасный город). Asia Plus reported at the time that Tajikistan authorities claimed the loan would be repayable through traffic violation fines.

title: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Macau) provides $120 million loan for Pakrut Gold Project (Linked to Project ID#54361, #70174, #70319, #70324, #70354, #70367, #70407, #70430)
description:
In 2012, China Nonferrous Metals International Mining Co. Ltd (CNMIM) provided a secured loan facility on commercial terms to Kryso Resources PLC — the mineral exploration and development company developing the Pakrut Gold Project —  for $10 million and RMB 530 million to finance the development of the Pakrut Gold Project (see linked Project ID#70174 and #70319).

Then, on June 19, 2014, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Macau) Limited provided a $120 million term loan facility to China Nonferrous Mining Group for the Pakrut Gold Project.
The loan was secured by standby letters of credit. The loans advanced under the facility could not exceed 95% of the value of the standby letters of credit. Standby letters of credit were issued on June 24, 2014 and June 18, 2015 in order to enable China Nonferrous Mining Group to drawdown $80 million and $40 million respectively under the facility. The principal loan repayments commenced on January 30, 2016. As of December 31, 2015, China Nonferrous Mining Group had fully drawn down the loan facility extended (see pg.29 of "Annual Report and Financial Statements for the Year Ended 31 December 2015"). The loan availability period ran from July 9, 2014 until June 19, 2015. If the facility was not fully drawn down within the loan availability period, the principal repayments were to be reduced in inverse order of the repayment schedule. In the event of default, ICBC had the right to demand full repayment of the outstanding loan and charge default interest at 3% over the contracted interest rate. The loan was secured by China Nonferrous. 

The interest rate on the loan was 2.90% per annum over the quarterly (3-month) LIBOR rate (average 3-month LIBOR rate in June 2014 was 0.231%). Therefore, the interest rate was coded as 2.90+.231=3.131%. The loan was repayable in USD. The principal loan repayment commenced on January 30, 2016 (see pg.29-30 of "Annual Report and Financial Statements for the Year Ended 31 December 2015").

The repayment schedule was as follows, denominated in USD (see pg.46 of "Annual Report and Financial Statements for the Year Ended 31 December 2015"):
- January 30, 2016 – $5,000,000
- July 30, 2016 – $10,000,000
- January 30, 2017 – $10,000,000
- July 30, 2017 – $15,000,000
- January 30, 2018 – $20,000,000
- July 30, 2018 – $20,000,000
- January 30, 2019 – $20,000,000
- June 8, 2019 – $20,000,000

LLC Pakrut, a mine that is 100% owned by Kryso Resources Ltd, operates the Pakrut deposit located on the southern slope of the Gissar range, 112 km from the city of Dushanbe (see "Final Results and Notice of AGM"). Relevant geological exploration at the Pakrut deposit began in 2004 (see pp.iii "Independent Technical Report of the Pakrut Gold Project in Vahdat Region, Republic of Tajikistan. 

According to the 2018 report published on Bloomberg, in November 2011, the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan issued a mining license to LLC Pakrut. According to SRK, at a gold cut-off of 1.0 g/t, the JORC Code compliant Proved Ore Reserves for Pakrut were estimated at 15,721 thousand tonnes (“kt”) averaging 3.1 g/t of gold. The JORC Code compliant Probable Ore Reserves were estimated at 2,787 kt averaging 2.5 g/t of gold. Construction started in September 2012. The project went into production on June 5, 2016. In February 2017, high levels of snowfall caused significant damage to the facilities and equipment, and interrupted the construction, which was restarted in the second half of 2017. All construction work was expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2018 and production was expected to be recommenced in April 2018.

This mining project is located in Vahdat District, Republic of Tajikistan, about 80 km northeast (“NE”) in a straight line (112 km by road) from Dushanbe, the country’s capital city. It sits on the southern slope of the Gissar range. More detailed locational information can be found at http://www.cnfgold.com/Managed/Resources/docs/Downloads/srk_report.pdf.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is "塔吉克斯坦帕克鲁特金矿."

title: Chinese Government loans RMB 50 million to restructure debt for Dushanbe Cigarette Factory Project
description:
In January 1997, Xinjiang International Economic Cooperation Corporation and Tadushanbe Cigarette Factory established a Sino-Tajik joint venture cigarette factory, the Dushanbe Cigarette Factory. The Chinese accounted for 10% of the registered capital ($300,000 USD), while Tajikistan accounted for 90%. The joint venture had a period of 30 years. The joint venture used a RMB 50 million government loan provided in 1994 to technically transform the tobacco factory, and the Chinese side provided cigarette and printing production lines. After the transformation, the production capacity of the factory was 5 billion cigarettes per year. The construction officially started in November 1998 and the project was completed in February 2001, and was officially handed over to Tajikistan in November 2001. However, the project was shelved because of tariff issues until October 2002. After that, the tobacco factory began trial production; producing 80 cases (800,000 cigarettes) of cigarettes per day, according to Economic and Commercial Office of the Chinese Embassy in Tajikistan in 2003.

The joint venture was to repay the RMB 50 million loan in installments from December 1, 2002. Since the joint venture tobacco factory was in a state of intermittent operation at that time, the supply of raw materials required was not timely, and revenue was not yet generated. So, Prime Minister Akilov of the Tajik government sent a letter to Premier Zhu Rongji in 2002 to propose debt relief or extension. A loan repayment proposal was then formally proposed with a loan period of 20 years, with a grace period of 5 years, with a reduced interest rate of 1%, according to the Economic and Commercial Office of the Chinese Embassy in Tajikistan in 2003. In 2006, the Economic and Commercial Office reported that the factory was looking for a Chinese company, in the form of our shareholding or other joint venture, to partner with it and introduce technical personnel, management experience and increase its working capital, so that the factory can operate normally.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is "杜尚别卷烟厂." The Russian title is "Душанбинская табачная фабрика."
sources: http://tj.mofcom.gov.cn/article/sqfb/200604/20060401905020.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://tj.mofcom.gov.cn/article/ztdy/200307/20030700109512.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: The Rudaki city division is coded for this project since the factory that was built from the loan is located in the city. The location of the factory can be found by searching in google maps the russian name of the factory: Душанбинская табачная фабрика

title: China donates furniture to Tajikistan
description: In 2008, the Chinese government donated furniture worth $410,960 to Tajikistan, as reported in the May 2018 Flat Export from Tajikistan AIMS. The project ID is TJK/082180. STAFF_NOTE: No additional information about this project could be found.

title: Chinese Cultural Exhibition Donated to Tajikistan
description: The exhibition called The Silk Route and Chinese Culture features silk, ceramics, porcelain, and tapestry. All in all, more than 200 exhibits. Chinese Ambassador Wu Hongbin, who opened the exhibition on Wednesday, said 'the Great Silk Route that linked the cultural centres in the huge area between China, the Mediterranean and Central Asia two thousand years ago lives on'. He expressed the hope that the exhibition will help strengthen friendship, cultural ties and trade between the two countries and their people. The diplomat said all exhibits will be donated to Tajikistan's Bekhzoda National Museum.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=tass000020030227dz2q004bm&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: The Rudaki city division is coded for this project since the musuem that received the loan is located in the city. The location of the museum was found by searching Bekhzod National Museum and the location is shown on mapcarta

title: Chinese Government grants Tajikistan $732,386 for natural disaster response (Linked to project ID#40409)
description: On June 11, 2010, Chinese President Hu Jintao announced that the Chinese Government would allocate a grant in assistance to Tajikistan to eliminate the consequences of that year's natural disasters.This project corresponds to TJK/102178 in the Tajikistan AIMS, which details a grant of $732,386 USD for 'Assistance in natural disaster'. At the same day, Chinese President Hu also announced another RMB 80 million RMB to support the Tajik economy, which is captured in project ID #40409. STAFF_NOTE: The media report showed that the transaction amount is RMB 5 million. Though Chinese are denominated in RMB in most cases, $732,386 USD was coded because it came from an official source.

title: Chinese Embassy donates Women's Sewing Training and Production Center in Dzhami District (Linked to Project ID#53594, #53591, #53587, #54043, #71883)
description:
The Chinese Embassy to Tajikistan donated a Women's Sewing Training Center in the Dzhami District. The opening ceremony was held on November 22, 2017. The center was intended to improve the vocational skills of local women and promote women's employment, according to the embassy. The value of the donated sewing center is unknown. 

Chinese Embassy also funded other differenct Women’s Sewing Training and Production Center in Tajikistan. Project ID#53594 captured the sewing center in Danghara. Project ID#54043 captured the sewing center in Maslozhelkomupo District, Dushanbe. Project ID#53591 captured the sewing center in Vakhsh District, Khatlon. Project ID#53587 captured the sewing center in Sino District, Dushanbe. Project ID#71883 captured the sewing center named "Gurdaston" in Dushanbe. 

STAFF_NOTE: "Year uncertain" was checked because it is not confirmed that this donation was committed in 2017. Translations state that this center was in the Khatlon Region "Zhami" or Tazami District", neither of which exist. After investigation, it became clear that those were different spellings for the "Dzhami District."
sources: http://tj.chineseembassy.org/chn/sbgx/t1513106.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: Jomi division is coded for this project since the sewing center in Dzhami district is located in this division. The location was found by searching Dzhami district into google maps which shows Jomi, Tajikistan.  This was double checked using GeoNames where searching Dzhami also shows Jomi as the higher adminstrative boundary

title: CNMIM provides $10 million loan for Pakrut Gold Project (Linked to Project ID#54361, #70220, #70319, #70324, #70354, #70367, #70407, #70430)
description:
On May 24, 2012, China Nonferrous Metals International Mining Co. Ltd (CNMIM) and Kryso Resources PLC signed a Shareholder Loan Agreement for a loan made on commercial terms to Kryso Resources PLC — the mineral exploration and development company developing the Pakrut Gold Project.

The secured loan facility consisted of two tranches; a tranche for RMB 530 million and a tranche for $10 million USD. It was to be used exclusively for the design, construction, operation and administration of the Pakrut Gold Project, including operating costs, capital expenditure, and general working capital. The USD tranche was disbursed by CNMIM transferring the funds into a designated bank account of the Kryso. The term of the loan went from the date of the first advance until May 31, 2017. The annual fixed interest rate was 9% for both tranches and a management fee at 0.5% on the total amount of the loan was paid within 30 days of the first advance. Default interest of 13.5% per annum was payable on overdue amounts on the tranches. The Group was to repay all amounts of principal and interest in respect in USD at the fixed exchange rate of $1 USD to 6.30 RMB. The repayment dates were May 31, 2015, November 11, 2015, May 31, 2016, November 11, 2016, and May 31, 2017 for both tranches. November 30, 2014 was the end of the loan availability period. Kryso had drawn down $10 million USD under the USD tranche. Kryso pledged its 100% equity interest in LLC Pakrut to CNMIM as security for repayment of the loan. 

This project only captures the USD tranche of the loan facility. For the RMB tranche, please see Project ID #70319.

LLC Pakrut, a mine that is 100% owned by Kryso Resources Ltd, operates the Pakrut deposit located on the southern slope of the Gissar range, 112 km from the city of Dushanbe (see "Final Results and Notice of AGM"). Relevant geological exploration at the Pakrut deposit began in 2004 (see pp.iii "Independent Technical Report of the Pakrut Gold Project  in Vahdat Region, Republic of Tajikistan. According to the 2018 report published on Bloomberg, in November 2011, the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan issued a mining license to LLC Pakrut. According to SRK, at a gold cut-off of 1.0 g/t, the JORC Code compliant Proved Ore Reserves for Pakrut were estimated at 15,721 thousand tonnes (“kt”) averaging 3.1 g/t of gold. The JORC Code compliant Probable Ore Reserves were estimated at 2,787 kt averaging 2.5 g/t of gold. Construction started in September 2012. The project went into production on June 5, 2016. In February 2017, high levels of snowfall caused significant damage to the facilities and equipment, and interrupted the construction, which was restarted in the second half of 2017. All construction work was expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2018 and production was expected to be recommenced in April 2018. 


This mining project is located in Vahdat District, Republic of Tajikistan, about 80 km northeast (“NE”) in a straight line (112 km by road) from Dushanbe, the country’s capital city. It sits on the southern slope of the Gissar range. More detailed locational information can be found at http://www.cnfgold.com/Managed/Resources/docs/Downloads/srk_report.pdf.

title: China and Tajikistan complete joint investigation on climate change
description: In September 2015, the Tajikistan academy of sciences invited researchers from the Institute of Urumqi Desert Meteorology of the China Meteorological Administration. The groups carried out an 8-day scientific investigation of climate change and water resources. The investigation is expected to bolster regional cooperation among countries in Asia and act as a foundation for future research of climate change in Central Asia countries.
sources: http://www.cma.gov.cn/en2014/news/News/201509/t20150923_293669.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: This project is coded up to country level since there is no specific location mentioned for where the research took place and the whole country may benefit from climate chang research

title: China Grants 31 Buses Worth 10 Million Yuan to Tajikistan
description: In July 3, 2000, on the eve of President of China Jiang Zemin's official visit to Tajikistan, 31 buses were dispatched to Dushanbe from China. The buses had been provided under free technical aid (10m yuans). An official ceremony for handing over the buses was 4th July, with the participation of the Chinese government's official delegation.

title: Chinese Government provides 1.4 million USD grant for 42nd Public School Water Supply Project in Dangara District
description:
On October 31, 2017, the groundbreaking ceremony of the 42nd Public School Water Supply Project in Dangara District, aided by the Chinese Government to the tune of 1.4 million USD, was held. Chinese Ambassador Yue Bin attended. This water supply project intended to provide clean water for the teachers and students of the 42nd School in Dangara District, and also solve the long-standing water-supply problem that has plagued local residents. An unspecified Chinese contractor was expected to be able to complete the project's construction on-time and deliver high-quality results. Dangara District is the hometown of President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon (see "驻塔吉克斯坦大使岳斌出席丹加拉区第42学校供水工程开工典礼" from the Chinese Embassy). TAG news Tajikistan reported that the project was funded by a $1.4 million USD grant from China, and involved the construction of a 5 km pipeline. The expected completion date was August 2018.

STAFF_NOTE: "Year uncertain" box was checked because it is not confirmed that this project was committed in 2017.
sources: http://tj.chineseembassy.org/chn/sbgx/t1506217.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://silkroadnews.org/en/news/chinese-firm-to-provide-drinking-water-to-school-and-village-in-dangara-in-tajikistan, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: Danghara Division is coded for this project since the school that was provided clean water was in this area.  The location was founded by searching Dangara district into google maps.

title: China opens Confucius Institute at Mining and Metallurgy Institute of Tajikistan
description: In 2014, Tajikistan's President Rahmon signed an agreement on the creation of a Confucius Institute at the Mining and Metallurgy Institute of Tajikistan. The agreement was signed in the presence of Xi Jinping and the Chief Executive of Confucius Institutes, Xu Lin. The Institute was formally created in 2015. The Institute provides lessons in Chinese and offers lessons in Chinese culture and music. It also offers scholarships to students in Tajikistan.
sources: http://english.hanban.org/node_45248.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://thediplomat.com/2017/05/tajikistan-takes-up-chinese/, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: Ghafurov division is coded for this project since Ckalovsk is located in this area and the school is located there.  The location of the school was found by searching  Mining and Metallurgy Institute of Tajikistan into google and the first geo source states which city the school is located in and the second geo source is where the city is located.

title: China Development Bank provides $140 million loan for Technological Innovation of ZGC Gold Mine (Linked to Project ID#72389, #72802, #40482, #40481, #69997)
description:
On May 19, 2013, China Development Bank (CDB) and Zijin Mining Group signed a loan agreement with JV Zeravshan LLC (formerly known as Zervashan Gold Company) -- a special purpose vehicle -- worth $140 million USD, according to the Times of Asia. The proceeds from the loan were to be used for the Technological Innovation of ZGC Gold Mine in Tajikistan, a project that aimed to expand the production capacity of a gold mine in the town of Panjakent within Zarafshon in northern Tajikistan.

According to pg. 37 of the 2013 Annual Report from Zijin (published March 28, 2014), the project had entered implementation and achieved the following objectives: (1) The stripping of infrastructure of Jilao open-pit mine and Taror openpit mine had been completed for over 90% and 80%, respectively; (2) The reformation of industrial pilot production processing technology of Taror oxide ore processing plant had been completed; and (3) The Jilao 10,000 tonnes processing plant project had entered into civil engineering construction and installation stage. Upon completion, the project was to increase the mine's production to 3.5 tonnes of gold per year.

This project was one of many signed during the same visit of the President of Tajikistan to China from May 19th 2013 to May 20th 2013. The other projects were: Loans totaling 33 million RMB to Amonatbonk (captured in project ID#69997), a 200 million RMB grant (captured in project ID#40481), an agreement for the reconstruction of Regar Substation (captured in project ID#40482), loans totaling 20 million USD to Amonatbonk (captured in project ID#72802), a technical cooperation agreement, a fruit inspection protocol, and a sports cooperation agreement. 

The project is linked to another Zijing Group stake acquisition project (captured in project ID#72389).

STAFF_NOTE: In 1994, Zeravshan Gold Company (ZGC) was launched as a joint venture with Nelson Resources Ltd (44%) and the Tajik Government (51%) and the IFC (5%). In September 2002, Avocet signed a heads of agreement to acquire the Tajik gold assets of Toronto-based Nelson Resources Ltd held through Nelson’s subsidiary, Commonwealth and British Minerals Ltd, including its 44% interest in ZGC. In November 2004, Avocet increased its equity interest in ZGC from 49% to 75%. In 2007, Zijin paid $429.8 million HKD to acquire Avocet's stake. In February 2018, Zijin Mining, sold 5% of its shares in JV Zarafshon (its new name) to the Tajik government for $1.00 USD. With this, Zijin's share decreased to 70% ($16,974,364 USD), while the Tajik government's share rose to 30% ($7,274,724 USD) (see "China’s Zijin Mining sells 5 percent of shares in JV Zarafshon to Tajik government for…1.00 USD").

title: China Development Bank loans $28 million to State Savings Bank of Tajikistan 'Amonatbonk' for crediting small and medium-sized businesses
description: On September 13, 2014, China Development Bank (CDB) and State Savings Bank of Tajikistan 'Amonatbonk' signed a master loan facility agreement worth $28 million. $10 million of this loan was to be spent crediting small and medium-sized businesses (see pg. 29 of English side of 'Amonatbonk 2014 Annual Report').
sources: http://www.president.tj/en/node/7501, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.amonatbonk.tj/upload/iblock/11f/annualreport20141.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.amonatbonk.tj/tj/about/news/2861/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: This project is coded up to country level since there are no specific locations of the small businesses that received the loan/credit

title: Chinese Government grants 105 vehicles worth $2.7 million USD to Tajikistan
description: On August 1, 2008, the Chinese Government handed over a total of 105 vehicles, consisting of 80 buses, five garbage trucks, and 20 executive cars for use during the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) summit to Tajikistan (see 'Tajikistan gets 105 Chinese vehicles'). This project appears to correspond to project TJK/082181 in the Tajikistan AIMS database, which captures the 'supply of buses and technical equipment for community facilities.' AIMS reported that the vehicles were worth $2,739,726 USD. STAFF_NOTE: Intent was coded as 'Mixed' because the provision of executive cars was for the SCO summit.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=ASIPLU0020080804e48400008&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCCA00020080801e481001b9&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://asiaplus.tj/en/news/tajikistan/power/20080731/china-donates-50-new-buses-tajik-capital, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dropbox.com/s/rl546mymjz3f15f/May%202018%20Flat%20Export%20from%20Tajikistan%20AIMS%20China%20Specific%20Projects.xlsx?dl=0 , Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China Construction Bank provides $20 million loan to China Nonferrous Gold Limited for working capital and restoring the production of Pakrut Gold Project (Linked to Project ID#54361, #70174, #70220, #70319, #70324, #70354, #70367, #70430)
description:
On May 24, 2012, China Nonferrous Metals International Mining Co. Ltd (CNMIM) provided a secured loan facility on commercial terms to Kryso Resources PLC — the mineral exploration and development company developing the Pakrut Gold Project — for $10 million and RMB 530 million to finance the development of the Pakrut Gold Project (see linked Project ID#70174 and #70319). Then, on June 19, 2014, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Macau) Limited provided a $120 million term loan facility to China Nonferrous Mining Group for the Pakrut Gold Project (see linked Project ID#70220). Then, on May 6, 2016, China Nonferrous Mining Group obtained a loan facility $120 million from CNMC International Capitals Company Limited (“CNMC”)— an associate of CNMIM — to refinance the loan facility that it contracted with Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Macau) Limited on June 19, 2014 for the Pakrut Gold Project (see linked Project ID#70324). On June 27, 2016 the China Nonferrous Mining Group obtained another loan, worth $19,114,809, from CNMIM for working capital purposes related to the Pakrut Gold Project (see linked Project ID#70354). Then, on July 1, 2016, China Construction Bank Corporation Macau Branch (CCBC) provided a loan facility of $100 million to China Nonferrous Mining Group to refinance its 2012 loan agreement with CNMIM (see linked Projects IDs #70367).

It was announced on October 30, 2017 that China Construction Bank Corporation Macau Branch agreed to provide China Nonferrous Gold with a loan facility of up to $20 million. The loan facility was for a maximum of one year and repayable 12 months after the first drawdown. The loan included an annual interest rate of 1.3% plus 3-month LIBOR and was governed by the law of Macau. The average 3-month LIBOR rate in October 2017 was 1.361%. Therefore, the interest rate was coded as 1.361+1.3=2.661%. The facility was secured by a standby letter of credit from China Construction Bank Corporation Beijing Branch, for the aggregate amount of $20,618,556.70, which expired 12 months after the date of first drawdown (1-year maturity). A standby letter of credit fee of 1.15% was payable per annum. The CCBC Loan was expected to be drawn down shortly after its signing and was to be used for working capital and to fund the restoration of production of the Pakrut gold mine (see "Financial Update" from October 30, 2017).

LLC Pakrut, a mine that is 100% owned by Kryso Resources Ltd, was first established in 2003 and it operates the Pakrut deposit located on the southern slope of the Gissar range, 107 km from the city of Dushanbe. The geological exploration at Pakrut deposit started in 2004. The pre-gold reserves at the deposit, approved by the State Reserves Committee (CRC) of the Republic of Tajikistan, were 28.1 tons. The reserves of Pakrut gold mine are currently estimated to be 100 tons. In November 2011, the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan issued a mining licence to LLC Pakrut. Construction started in September 2012. The project went into production on June 5, 2016. In February 2017, high levels of snowfall caused significant damage to the facilities and equipment, and interrupted the construction, which was restarted in the second half of 2017. All construction work was expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2018 and production was expected to be recommenced in April 2018.

This mining project is located in Vahdat District, Republic of Tajikistan, about 80 km northeast (“NE”) in a straight line (112 km by road) from Dushanbe, the country’s capital city. It sits on the southern slope of the Gissar range. More detailed locational information can be found at http://www.cnfgold.com/Managed/Resources/docs/Downloads/srk_report.pdf. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is "塔吉克斯坦帕克鲁特金矿."

title: China Development Bank funds for new office building of the Board of the State Savings Bank of Tajikistan 'Amonatbonk' (Linked to project ID#40488)
description:
China Development Bank (CDB) provided funds for a new office building for the Board of State Savings Bank of the Republic of Tajikistan "Amonatbank". In addition to CDB's funding, Amonatbank contributed its own funds towards the project. The total cost of the construction amounted to more than 90 million Tajikistani Somonis. The project is located is located at 105 Rudaki Avenue, Dushanbe and included 10 floors and two underground floors for the parking of service cars and a warehouse. The construction term was three years. The contractor for the construction of the building was Rohat-Sokhtmon Limited Liability Company. 

The ceremony for the laying of the first stone was held on March 13, 2015, and was attended by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon (see "Сохтмони бинои нави БДА ҶТ “Амонатбонк” оғоз гардид."). It appears that the building featured a museum and was completed by January 18, 2020, as it had visitors (see "Ташрифи собиқадорони «Амонатбонк» ба бинои нави Раёсати БДА ҶТ «Амонатбонк».")

The project is linked to another funding from People's Bank of China for the same construction project, which was captured in project ID#40488. 

STAFF_NOTE: "Year uncertain" was checked because it is not confirmed that CDB's involvement in this project was committed in 2015. CDB's exact share of the 90 million TJS and the flow type are both unknown. Three language versions of the same article exist from Amonatbonk; each were used to create this project.
sources: https://amonatbonk.tj/en/about/news/3197/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://amonatbonk.tj/ru/about/news/3091/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.amonatbonk.tj/tj/about/news/2876/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://amonatbonk.tj/tj/about/news/5420/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: The Rudaki city division is coded for this project since the building that received funding for renovations is located in Dushanb.  The location of the building can be found searching the address into google maps. The address is provided in the project description

title: China provides irrigation methods and farming techniques to Tajik communities
description: In late January 2011, the Government of Tajikistan agreed to lease out 2,000 hectares of land to the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region (XUAR). The deal was to bring 1,500 Chinese farmers to work the fields in the Qumsangir District and Bokhtar District of southern Khatlon Province. The Chinese promised to introduce drip-irrigation methods and other contemporary farming techniques to the region, and share their expertise and technology with Tajik communities (see 'Tajikistan Agrees To Allow Chinese Farmers To Till Land'). The deal was formally signed in March 2011, and Chinese farmers were already at work at that time. It was reported that the Tajik government believed the Chinese farmers would help revitalize the rural communities and boost food security (see 'Tajik land deal extends China's reach in Central Asia'). STAFF_NOTE: Intent was coded as 'Mixed' because leasing land is commercial, but there are development goals in helping the Tajik rural communities. This project is not to be confused with a 6,000 hectare land-lease in 2012 (project ID#72392).
sources: https://eurasianet.org/tajikistan-agrees-to-allow-chinese-farmers-to-till-land, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tajikistan-china-land-idUSTRE72O1RP20110325, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.rferl.org/a/tajikistan_china/2289623.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://rsa.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/15387216.2016.1238313, Academic Journal Article
GEO_notes: Bokhtar and Qumsangir divisions are coded for this project as the project description mentions this is where the farmers were sent to and benefitted from this. The locations of the divisions can be found by searching the names into google maps (Qumsangir)

title: China Development Bank provides $70.6 million loan to CJSC TK Mobile for CDMA National Network Project (Linked to Project ID#71575)
description:
In December 2006, the China Development Bank (CDB) provided a US $70.6 million loan to Closed Joint-Stock Company CJSC TK Mobile (a Tajik-Chinese mobile phone operator). The loan was meant to be used to finance the CDMA National Network Project and the purchasing of equipment and services from ZTE. The loan has a maturity of 9 years. In May 2019, ZTE provided a guarantee by pledging its 51% equity interest in CJSC TK Mobile as the provision of guarantee, with a term from the date on which the Agreement on the Pledge of Equity Interests is executed and becomes effective to the date on which the debts owed by CJSC TK Mobile under the financing documents are fully repaid. 

The CDMA National Network Project entailed the purchase of telecommunications equipment, relevant software and services for the construction of the CDMA 800M national network in Tajikistan.

STAFF_NOTE: CJSC TK Mobile is a telecommunications operator established in Tajikistan in December 2003 as a joint venture by ZTE and Service Svyaz Komplect (‘‘CCK’’) with a registered capital of US$4,000,000. ZTE held a 51% ownership stake and CCK owned a 49% ownership stake (see linked project ID#71575).
sources: https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2012/02/chinese-telecoms-may-be-spying-on-large-numbers-of-foreign-customers/253185/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.zte.com.cn/mi_imgs/global/investor_relations/353002/P020120918590664549799.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://asiaplustj.info/en/news/tajikistan/20061221/cdb-provides-70-million-loan-cellular-operator-tajikistan, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://asiaplustj.info/en/news/tajikistan/economic/20180411/tk-mobile-withdraw-from-countrys-telecommunications-market, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: This project is coded up to country level since there is no location mentioned where the mobile network was benefitted; there may be more than one area that benefitted

title: China Eximbank provides $35.4 million government concessional loan for Tajik Aluminum Company (TALCO) to launch three new plants (Linked to Project ID#53755)
description:
On July 24, 2014, Tajik Aluminum Company (TALCO) signed an EPC agreement with China National Heavy Machinery Corporation (CHMC) for the Fluoride Salt Project. The project included the construction of three large plants in the Yovon District of Khatlon Region: a plant for the production of aluminum fluoride with annual capacity of 18,000 tons, a plant for the production of cryolite with annual capacity of 12,000 tons, and the plant for the production of sulfuric acid with annual capacity of 130,000 tons. These three plants were sometimes referred to as three separate projects: the Cryolite Project, the Aluminum Fluoride Project, and the Sulfuric Acid Project. 

The total cost of these projects was roughly $126 million USD. TALCO itself will invest approximately $37 million in the plants. On November 7, 2014, to finance the rest of the project, during the Beijing APEC Summit and under the witness of Xi Jinping and President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon (see "塔铝项目贷款协议正式签订" from CNMC), the Export-Import Bank of China agreed to provide two loans to the Tajik Ministry of Finance for the Flouride Salt Project: a RMB-denominated government concessional loan (GCL) provided on highly concessional terms (20 year maturity, 11 year grace period, and 1.5% interest rate) and a $53.1 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan on highly concessional terms (2% interest rate, 20 year maturity, 9 year grace period).

The precise face value of the GCL loan and the precise face value of the PBC loan are unknown. However, it is known that the GCL and PBC are jointly worth $88.5 million, and AidData learned through correspondence with the IMF that 40% of the total debt financing from China Eximbank ($35.4 million) came from the RMB-denominated GCL and 60% of the total debt financing from China Eximbank ($53.1 million) came from the USD-denominated PBC. The loan agreements were finalized between Ministry of Finance and China Eximbank on November 7, 2014. Project ID#53755 records the PBC and Project ID#71391 records the GCL. They were then ratified by the Tajik Parliament on January 14, 2015. 

The project was located in Yovon District within Khatlon Region. Its exact locational coordinates are 38° 32' 45"N, 68° 13' 31" E (see "TALCO" from Sulphuric Acid on the Web). Construction was undertaken by the EPC contractor (CHMC) and these three plants were completed and officially inaugurated by Tajikistan President Emomali Rahmon on September 6, 2016.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese name of the project is 塔铝项目. The Russian name of the project is Строительство заводов по производству криолита, фтористого алюминия и серной кислоты в рамках реконструкции и модернизации ТАЛКО. 

Aluminum fluoride is an inorganic compound used primarily in the production of aluminum. This colorless solid can be prepared synthetically, but also occurs naturally. Aluminum fluoride is an important additive for the production of aluminum by electrolysis. Together, with cryolite, it lowers the melting point to below 1000°C and increases the conductivity of the solution. Cryolite was historically used as an ore of aluminum, and later in the electrolytic processing of the aluminum-rich oxide ore bauxite. The difficulty of separating aluminum from oxygen in the oxide ores was overcome by the use of cryolite as a flux to dissolve the oxide minerals. Pure cryolite melts at 1012°C, and it can dissolve the aluminum oxides sufficiently to allow for the easy extraction of the aluminum by electrolysis. Substantial energy is still needed for both heating the materials and the electrolysis, but it is much more energy-efficient than melting the oxides themselves. Since natural cryolite is too rare to be used for this purpose, synthetic sodium aluminum fluoride is produced from the common mineral fluorite. Sulfuric acid has a wide range of applications, including domestic acidic drain cleaner, electrolyte in lead-acid batteries, and various cleaning agents. It is also a central substance in the chemical industry. Principal uses include mineral processing, fertilizer manufacturing, oil refining, wastewater processing, and chemical synthesis. It is widely produced with different methods, such as contact process, wet sulfuric acid process and some other methods (see "http://www.sulphuric-acid.com/sulphuric-acid-on-the-web/acid%20plants/TALCO.htm").

The Tajik Aluminum Company is one of the ten largest aluminum smelters in the world. It provides up to 70% of Tajikistan's foreign currency earnings while consuming 40% of its electrical power. TALCO is wholly owned by the Tajik Government. Tajikistan does not mine alumina, but imports the raw material through tolling arrangements.

title: Chinese Government grants $20,400 to Tajikistan for Meteorological Management
description: In 2004, the Government of the People's Republic of China provided a grant of $20,400 for a project in Tajikistan for the meteorological management of the PRC, according to the Tajikistan AIMS platform (AIMS ID: TJK/042055). STAFF_NOTE: This project was listed in the Tajikistan AIMS platform, which indicates that funds did go to Tajikistan, however the source indicated that the funding was used for meteorological management of People's Republic of China.
sources: https://www.dropbox.com/s/rl546mymjz3f15f/May%202018%20Flat%20Export%20from%20Tajikistan%20AIMS%20China%20Specific%20Projects.xlsx?dl=0 , Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

title: China Eximbank provides $26.4 million preferential buyer’s credit for Unified Power System in Northern Tajikistan Project
description:
On July 20, 2011, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a $26,463,789 USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement with the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan for the Unified Power System in Northern Tajikistan Project. This loan carried a 20-year maturity, a grace period of 5 to 7 years, and a 2% interest rate (see "List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018"). The entire project had a cost of $27,857,000 million USD. The Government of Tajikistan contributed $1.4 million USD to the project.

The Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from this PBC loan to on-lend — through subsidiary loan agreement No. 2011(19) TOTAL (170) – 030 BT, dated July 20, 2011 — to Open Joint Stock Holding Company (OHSHC) “Barqi Tojik” at a 3% interest rate between July 20, 2011 and March 21, 2031. OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy.

According to Asia-Plus, the loan was to be used to finance the construction of a new substation, Sughd-500, because the operating substation, Khujand-500, was not able to ensure regular electricity supplies to northern Tajikistan through the 550 kV South-North power transmission line (also Chinese-financed, project ID #39644 and #70910). Construction of the Sughd-500 substation was also intended to promote the implementation of the Central Asia South Asia Electricity Trade and Transmission Project (CASA 1000), which aimed to establish the necessary transmission and trading infrastructure and systems to enable a trade of surplus electricity from Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan to Afghanistan and Pakistan.

Chinese company TBEA was responsible for implementation. According to Asia-Plus, the project was to begin in October 2011 and be finished by the end of the year. However, the completed project was not accepted by Tajikistan until March 15, 2013 (approved by the government on October 4, 2013) (see "Постановление Правительства Республики Таджикистан от 4 октября 2013 года, № 444...").

This project involved the construction of a unified power system/single power grid through the construction of a new substation, Sughd-500, in the north of Tajikistan, near Jamoat Lolazor in Devashtich District. More locational details can be found at https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/project-documents/52122/52122-001-rp-en.pdf.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Проект создания единой электрической системы севера Республики Таджикистан. In English, it is also sometimes referred to as the Sughd 500/220 kV Substation/ single power grid for the north of Tajikistan. The AIMS project ID is TJK/112373. 

Additionally, in October 2011, Minister of Finance Safarali Najmiddinov said that the loan had an annual interest rate of 2.0 percent for 33 years with a seven-year grace period, as relayed by Asia-Plus. However, according to the IMF in 2018, this loan had a maturity of 20 years, a grace period from 5 to 7 years, and an annual interest rate of 2% interest rate. With all this in mind, the interest rate was coded as 2%, the maturity period was coded 20 years, and the grace period was coded as missing.

title: Peking University donates 100 desktop computers and related equipment to Tajikistan for hosting of International Decade for Action 'Water for Life' conference
description: On June 9, 2010, Peking University donated 100 desktop computers and related equipment to Tajikistan so it could hold the international conference for the International Decade for Action 'Water for Life', according to the Chinese Embassy to Tajikistan. After the conference, the computers were to be used in Tajik universities for teaching and scientific research. The total value of the donated computers is not known. STAFF_NOTE: 2010 was coded as the commitment year because the computers were handed over at that time; the actual year of commitment is not known, hence the Year Uncertain designation. Education was selected as CRS sector because these computers were ultimately going to Tajik universities.
sources: http://tj.china-embassy.org/chn/xwdt/t707734.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://tj.china-embassy.org/chn/xwdt/t708089.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: This project is coded up to country level since multiple universities ended up using the equipment donations, and there was no specific location of where the donation was received

title: Chinese Embassy Supports Guldasta Sewing Center in Varzob District
description: On December 10, 2014 the Chinese embassy in Tajikistan assisted in the opening of the 'Guldasta' sewing center in teh Varzob District, located 25 km north of Tajikistan's capital. Zhao Syanzhun, wife of the Chinese Ambassador participated in the opening ceremony along with the chairman of the Varzob district and a representative from the People's Democratic Party. The embassy donated 20 sewing machines, scissors sets, irons, and other necessary equipment. STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese embassy press release specified that this is the second sewing training center donated to Tajikistan. The project needs to be distinguished from the first center that was transferred in June 2014 (project 54043).
sources: http://www.avesta.tj/eng/4732-chinese-embassy-supports-to-open-sewing-center-in-varzob-district.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://tj.china-embassy.org/chn/xwdt/t1218176.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: Varzob division is coded for this project.  The Varzob district received the sewing material donations which is located in the Varzob division.  The location can be found by searching 'varzob' into google maps. The project description mentions it is north of the capital, which can be seen on google maps that it is near Dushanbe.

title: Chinese Embassy provides 'Ambassador Scholarships' to 25 Tajik students (Linked to Project ID#71853)
description: On November 30, 2017, during an 'Open Day' at the Chinese Embassy in Tajikistan, Chinese Ambassador Yue Bin awarded 'Ambassador Scholarships' to 25 outstanding students selected from more than 4,000 Tajikistan students who learned Chinese in Confucius School. The value of the scholarships is not known. STAFF_NOTE: This project is linked to project ID#71853, which captured a project for 25 Ambassador Scholarships presented by the Chinese Embassy during an 'Open Day' event on May 11, 2018.
sources: http://tj.chineseembassy.org/chn/sbgx/t1515712.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: This project is coded up to country level since it is unclear which schools had the students that received scholarships; there are multiple "Tajikistan University"s, "Middle School"s and "Confucius Institute"s in Tajikistan

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 59.6 million grant for Phase 2 of the Kurgan-Tyube to Kulob Road Rehabilitation Project (Linked to Project ID#71741 and #72612)
description:
In 2013, the Chinese Government agreed to provide RMB 58.4 million of grant financing for Phase 1 of the the Kurgan-Tyube to Kulob Road Rehabilitation Project (captured in project ID#71741). Then, in 2016, the Chinese Government agreed to provide RMB 59.6 million of grant financing for Phase 2 of the the Kurgan-Tyube to Kulob Road Rehabilitation Project (captured in project ID#53990).

The first phase of the project involved the construction of 12 kilometers of roads in Kurgan-Tyube and Kulob and 2 automobile bridges in Kulob. The second phase of the project involved the rehabilitation of 15 streets and 4 bridges in Kurgan-Tyube and Kulob measuring 22 km in length. 

China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The project was supervised and managed by China Railway First Survey and Design Institute Group Co.,Ltd. 

The first phase officially started on April 17, 2015. The inauguration ceremony and the signing ceremony of the technology handover certificate for project was held on January 19, 2016. The second phase of construction began on December 29, 2016. It was completed on December 15, 2017, after passing inspection. The Project Qualification Certificate was signed on December 27, 2007. The inaugural ceremony for the second phase was held on January 8, 2018.

STAFF_NOTE: : This project is also known as the Road Rehabilitation Project for Two Cities in Tajikistan. The Chinese project title is 塔吉克斯坦两城市道路修复项目（第II阶段).

title: China Eximbank provides $281.1 million preferential buyer’s credit for the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#40351)
description:
On June 15, 2006, at the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) summit, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed a $281,105,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project. The PBC loan carried a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period of 5 to 7 years, and an interest rate of 2% (see loan details at "List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018"). 

The loan was set to disburse in 3 annual tranches. The loan disbursements were as follows (see pg.7 of "INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND REPUBLIC OF TAJIKISTAN Staff Report for the 2006 Article IV Consultation"):
- 2007: $112.4 million USD
- 2008: $112.4 million USD
- 2009: $56.2 million USD

The project had a total cost of $295.9 million USD. This project is linked to project ID#40351, a RMB 60 million grant offered by the Chinese Government. China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on July 11, 2006. The construction period was planned to be 38 months. The highway was commissioned in 2010, but work continued on the Shahristan  tunnel. The project was completed on October 27, 2012, with an opening ceremony for the Shahristan tunnel that was attended by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. 

Earlier, in March 2006, China and Tajikistan signed a Memorandum of Understanding that stated the terms of preferential credits issuance for promotion of economic and social development of SCO members. One of the financing projects identified was this road project. The purpose of the project — also known as the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project — was to reconstruct the 354 km highway connecting Dushanbe with Khujand, the center of the northern province, and the town of Chanak on the border with Uzbekistan. The project also involved the construction of the 5253 meter Shahristan tunnel (at a cost of $88,424), the 1047 meter Dusti tunnel, the Maikhura tunnel, 39 big and small bridges, and 6 km of avalanche defenses. More detailed locational information is available at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbe-chanak-highway-including-shahristan-and-dusty-tunnels-rehabilitation/d0fdfa30-2790-41ab-8462-fb056c335c52/.

The project reportedly reduced driving times from 12 hours to 4 hours and the Shahristan tunnel was reportedly the longest tunnel in Central Asia when it completed, according to China Global Television Network. To help repay the loan and cover the costs of maintaining the road, the Tajik Government made the highway a toll road in 2010 and allowed the private company Innovative Road Solutions to collected tolls. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is реабилитацию автомобильной дороги «Душанбе – Чанак». The Chinese project title is 塔乌（乌兹别克斯坦）公路.

title: China Eximbank provides $281.1 million preferential buyer’s credit for the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#40351)
description:
On June 15, 2006, at the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) summit, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed a $281,105,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project. The PBC loan carried a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period of 5 to 7 years, and an interest rate of 2% (see loan details at "List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018"). 

The loan was set to disburse in 3 annual tranches. The loan disbursements were as follows (see pg.7 of "INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND REPUBLIC OF TAJIKISTAN Staff Report for the 2006 Article IV Consultation"):
- 2007: $112.4 million USD
- 2008: $112.4 million USD
- 2009: $56.2 million USD

The project had a total cost of $295.9 million USD. This project is linked to project ID#40351, a RMB 60 million grant offered by the Chinese Government. China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on July 11, 2006. The construction period was planned to be 38 months. The highway was commissioned in 2010, but work continued on the Shahristan  tunnel. The project was completed on October 27, 2012, with an opening ceremony for the Shahristan tunnel that was attended by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. 

Earlier, in March 2006, China and Tajikistan signed a Memorandum of Understanding that stated the terms of preferential credits issuance for promotion of economic and social development of SCO members. One of the financing projects identified was this road project. The purpose of the project — also known as the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project — was to reconstruct the 354 km highway connecting Dushanbe with Khujand, the center of the northern province, and the town of Chanak on the border with Uzbekistan. The project also involved the construction of the 5253 meter Shahristan tunnel (at a cost of $88,424), the 1047 meter Dusti tunnel, the Maikhura tunnel, 39 big and small bridges, and 6 km of avalanche defenses. More detailed locational information is available at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbe-chanak-highway-including-shahristan-and-dusty-tunnels-rehabilitation/d0fdfa30-2790-41ab-8462-fb056c335c52/.

The project reportedly reduced driving times from 12 hours to 4 hours and the Shahristan tunnel was reportedly the longest tunnel in Central Asia when it completed, according to China Global Television Network. To help repay the loan and cover the costs of maintaining the road, the Tajik Government made the highway a toll road in 2010 and allowed the private company Innovative Road Solutions to collected tolls. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is реабилитацию автомобильной дороги «Душанбе – Чанак». The Chinese project title is 塔乌（乌兹别克斯坦）公路.

title: China Eximbank provides $281.1 million preferential buyer’s credit for the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#40351)
description:
On June 15, 2006, at the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) summit, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed a $281,105,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project. The PBC loan carried a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period of 5 to 7 years, and an interest rate of 2% (see loan details at "List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018"). 

The loan was set to disburse in 3 annual tranches. The loan disbursements were as follows (see pg.7 of "INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND REPUBLIC OF TAJIKISTAN Staff Report for the 2006 Article IV Consultation"):
- 2007: $112.4 million USD
- 2008: $112.4 million USD
- 2009: $56.2 million USD

The project had a total cost of $295.9 million USD. This project is linked to project ID#40351, a RMB 60 million grant offered by the Chinese Government. China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on July 11, 2006. The construction period was planned to be 38 months. The highway was commissioned in 2010, but work continued on the Shahristan  tunnel. The project was completed on October 27, 2012, with an opening ceremony for the Shahristan tunnel that was attended by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. 

Earlier, in March 2006, China and Tajikistan signed a Memorandum of Understanding that stated the terms of preferential credits issuance for promotion of economic and social development of SCO members. One of the financing projects identified was this road project. The purpose of the project — also known as the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project — was to reconstruct the 354 km highway connecting Dushanbe with Khujand, the center of the northern province, and the town of Chanak on the border with Uzbekistan. The project also involved the construction of the 5253 meter Shahristan tunnel (at a cost of $88,424), the 1047 meter Dusti tunnel, the Maikhura tunnel, 39 big and small bridges, and 6 km of avalanche defenses. More detailed locational information is available at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbe-chanak-highway-including-shahristan-and-dusty-tunnels-rehabilitation/d0fdfa30-2790-41ab-8462-fb056c335c52/.

The project reportedly reduced driving times from 12 hours to 4 hours and the Shahristan tunnel was reportedly the longest tunnel in Central Asia when it completed, according to China Global Television Network. To help repay the loan and cover the costs of maintaining the road, the Tajik Government made the highway a toll road in 2010 and allowed the private company Innovative Road Solutions to collected tolls. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is реабилитацию автомобильной дороги «Душанбе – Чанак». The Chinese project title is 塔乌（乌兹别克斯坦）公路.

title: China Eximbank provides $281.1 million preferential buyer’s credit for the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#40351)
description:
On June 15, 2006, at the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) summit, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed a $281,105,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project. The PBC loan carried a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period of 5 to 7 years, and an interest rate of 2% (see loan details at "List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018"). 

The loan was set to disburse in 3 annual tranches. The loan disbursements were as follows (see pg.7 of "INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND REPUBLIC OF TAJIKISTAN Staff Report for the 2006 Article IV Consultation"):
- 2007: $112.4 million USD
- 2008: $112.4 million USD
- 2009: $56.2 million USD

The project had a total cost of $295.9 million USD. This project is linked to project ID#40351, a RMB 60 million grant offered by the Chinese Government. China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on July 11, 2006. The construction period was planned to be 38 months. The highway was commissioned in 2010, but work continued on the Shahristan  tunnel. The project was completed on October 27, 2012, with an opening ceremony for the Shahristan tunnel that was attended by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. 

Earlier, in March 2006, China and Tajikistan signed a Memorandum of Understanding that stated the terms of preferential credits issuance for promotion of economic and social development of SCO members. One of the financing projects identified was this road project. The purpose of the project — also known as the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project — was to reconstruct the 354 km highway connecting Dushanbe with Khujand, the center of the northern province, and the town of Chanak on the border with Uzbekistan. The project also involved the construction of the 5253 meter Shahristan tunnel (at a cost of $88,424), the 1047 meter Dusti tunnel, the Maikhura tunnel, 39 big and small bridges, and 6 km of avalanche defenses. More detailed locational information is available at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbe-chanak-highway-including-shahristan-and-dusty-tunnels-rehabilitation/d0fdfa30-2790-41ab-8462-fb056c335c52/.

The project reportedly reduced driving times from 12 hours to 4 hours and the Shahristan tunnel was reportedly the longest tunnel in Central Asia when it completed, according to China Global Television Network. To help repay the loan and cover the costs of maintaining the road, the Tajik Government made the highway a toll road in 2010 and allowed the private company Innovative Road Solutions to collected tolls. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is реабилитацию автомобильной дороги «Душанбе – Чанак». The Chinese project title is 塔乌（乌兹别克斯坦）公路.

The project had a total cost of $295.9 million USD. This project is linked to project ID#40351, a RMB 60 million grant offered by the Chinese Government. China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on July 11, 2006. The construction period was planned to be 38 months. The highway was commissioned in 2010, but work continued on the Shahristan  tunnel. The project was completed on October 27, 2012, with an opening ceremony for the Shahristan tunnel that was attended by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. 

Earlier, in March 2006, China and Tajikistan signed a Memorandum of Understanding that stated the terms of preferential credits issuance for promotion of economic and social development of SCO members. One of the financing projects identified was this road project. The purpose of the project — also known as the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project — was to reconstruct the 354 km highway connecting Dushanbe with Khujand, the center of the northern province, and the town of Chanak on the border with Uzbekistan. The project also involved the construction of the 5253 meter Shahristan tunnel (at a cost of $88,424), the 1047 meter Dusti tunnel, the Maikhura tunnel, 39 big and small bridges, and 6 km of avalanche defenses. More detailed locational information is available at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbe-chanak-highway-including-shahristan-and-dusty-tunnels-rehabilitation/d0fdfa30-2790-41ab-8462-fb056c335c52/.

The project reportedly reduced driving times from 12 hours to 4 hours and the Shahristan tunnel was reportedly the longest tunnel in Central Asia when it completed, according to China Global Television Network. To help repay the loan and cover the costs of maintaining the road, the Tajik Government made the highway a toll road in 2010 and allowed the private company Innovative Road Solutions to collected tolls. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is реабилитацию автомобильной дороги «Душанбе – Чанак». The Chinese project title is 塔乌（乌兹别克斯坦）公路.

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 191.9 million government concessional loan for the Upgrade of the Vahdat-Yavan Section of the Dushanbe-Kurgantube Railway Project (Linked to Project ID#71443)
description:
On November 7, 2014, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed two loan agreements with the Export-Import Bank of China for the Upgrade of the Vahdat-Yavan Section of the Dushanbe-Kurgantube Railway Project: a RMB-denominated government concessional loan (GCL) provided on highly concessional terms (20 year maturity, 11 year grace period, and 1.5% interest rate) and a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan on highly concessional terms (2% interest, 20 year maturity, 9 year grace period), each with a bank service fee of 0.2% and a reservation fee of 0.2%).

On August 13, 2013, State Unitary Enterprise “Rohi Ohani Tojikiston” had signed a contract for the survey, design and construction of tunnels and bridges of the new Dushanbe-Kurgan-Tyube railway, Vahdat-Yavan section for $59,993,900 USD. The Government of Tajikistan approved this deal on August 28, 2013, and ordered the Ministry of Finance to attract a soft loan from China Eximbank. The total cost of the project was approximately $71.993 million USD. The loans from the Export-Import Bank of China were valued at $68,992,970 USD. Tajikistan contributed $2,999,700 USD through State Unitary Enterprise "Rohi Ohani Tojikiston” (see "Information on existing state investment projects" and "Строительство мостов и тоннелей на железной дороги Душанбе-Кургантюбе, участок Вахдат-Яван" from the Ministry of Transport of the Republic of Tajikistan).

The face value of the GCL loan was RMB 191.9 million. The face value of the PBC loan was $36.9 million USD (pg.5 of “Отчет о состоянии государственного долга на 2014 год”). These loans combined are roughly equal to the reported Eximbank contribution. The loans were ratified by the Tajik Parliament on January 14, 2015. Project ID#40489 records the GCL and Project ID#71443 records the PBC. 

This project was to become the first railway project launched and completed under the framework of the "Silk Road Economic Belt" initiative, and was to become a hub of an international railway network connecting China, Tajikistan, Afghanistan, and Iran. China Railway 19th Bureau Group Co Ltd was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on May 15, 2015 and the project was completed on August 24, 2016. 

This project involved the construction of construction of 5 bridges and 3 tunnels along the Vakhdat-Yavan section of the Dushanbe-Kurgantube railway. Additional locational details can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/vahdat-yavan-railway-construction/bde10173-33b5-4431-9ad2-19468648bcbd/.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Строительство железной дороги Душанбе-Курган-тюбе, участок Вахдат- Яван. Yavan is also spelled Yovon. Vahdat is also spelled Vakhdat.

title: China grants construction materials and diesel generators for disaster response in Tajikistan
description: In 2009, China granted construction materials and diesel generators for disaster response in the areas in Tajikistan affected by torrential rains and mudflows. The total value of the aid was estimated at 30,000 USD by REACT (Rapid Emergency Assessment and Coordination Team). This aid was in response to the May 2009 floods in Tajikistan.
sources: https://reliefweb.int/disaster/fl-2009-000095-tjk, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.tj.undp.org/content/dam/tajikistan/docs/library/UNDP_TJK_DPP_2012_Eng.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.humanitarianresponse.info/sites/www.humanitarianresponse.info/files/documents/files/2009_tajikistan_react_appeal.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: Rudaki (city), Turunzoda, Shahrituz, Khuroson Divisions are coded for this division since these were the areas affected by the floods, the areas that were affected can be found in the geosource (Rudaki)
