title: Chinese Government grants aid worth $640,640 to Tajik Ministry of Internal Affairs
description: In 2002, the Chinese Ministry of Public Security and the Tajik Ministry of Internal Affairs (also known as the Ministry of the Interior) signed an agreement on the fight against terrorism, extremism and separatism, which included the provision of no-strings aid to Tajikistan. The aid was handed over on March 11, 2003. The aid consisted of twenty patrol cars (Radio Free Europe suggests it was 50 vehicles), special equipment, computers, laser printers, uniforms and footwear for the ministry's special subdivisions, special crime detection equipment, communication devices, night vision binoculars, cameras, metal detectors, shields, and helmets, among other goods (see BBC's 'Tajik police get 0.7m-dollar aid from China'). Material for bomb defusal was also included. Media sources indicate that the value of the aid was $700,000. However, according to the Flat Export from Tajikistan AIMS as of May 2018, the Chinese government funded 'Policemen facilities' (AIMS project ID TJK/042056) worth $483,600. Additionally, there was an additional contribution of $157,040 USD for 'Different kind of equipment' (AIMS project ID TJK/042058). Together, these two donations totaled $640,640, therefore it seems they are referencing this same project, even though transaction amounts differ slightly, so the transaction amount was coded as $640,640 USD to reflect official source information.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=afpr000020030312dz3c003ej&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=bbcca00020030311dz3b000b7&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1102748.html, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); http://reliefweb.int/report/tajikistan/china-gives-tajikistan-2-million-dollars-food-aid, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dropbox.com/s/rl546mymjz3f15f/May%202018%20Flat%20Export%20from%20Tajikistan%20AIMS%20China%20Specific%20Projects.xlsx?dl=0 , Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
factiva_sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=afpr000020030312dz3c003ej&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=bbcca00020030311dz3b000b7&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: This project is coded up to country level since there is no specific location that received aid but multipe areas may have beneffited from this exchange.

title: Chinese Government grants $1,223,241 for the repair of Shar-Shar (Ozodi) Tunnel Access Road (Linked to Project ID#40406, #40063, #53750, #40440)
description:
In 2013, the Chinese Government provided a $1,223,241 grant for the repair of a 6km access road to the Shar Shar (Ozodi) Tunnel. The total cost of the project was $2.185 million USD. The project included the repair of the connection line base, the road surface, and the addition of water pipe bridges. 

China Railway No.5 Engineering Group, a subsidiary company of China Railway Engineering Corporation (CREC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. SIPPR Engineering Group Co., Ltd.  was responsible for construction supervision. Construction began in September 2013, and the project was completed in September 2014.

STAFF_NOTE: A 2018 export from the Government of Tajikistan’s Aid Information Management System (AIMS) identifies the face value of the grant as $1,223,241 (see AIMS project ID# TJK/112262) (see “May 2018 Flat Export from Tajikistan AIMS China Specific Projects”). This project is linked to project ID #40406, which was an RMB 260 million grant for the construction of the tunnel in 2006. It also linked to a series of China Eximbank-financed road segments along the Dushanbe-Dangara section of the Dushanbe-Kulma highway (Project ID#40063, Project ID#53750, and Project ID#40440). 

The Russian title of this project is Ремонт подходных путей к тоннелю Озоди (Шар-Шар). The Chinese title of this project is 援塔吉克斯坦沙尔-沙尔隧道南北连接线修复项目. The Shar-Shar tunnel was renamed the Ozodi (in English: Liberty) tunnel in 2014 (see "Chormaghzak Tunnel renamed Khatlon Tunnel and Shar-Shar Tunnel renamed Ozodi Tunnel"). The provision year of the grant was assumed based on the start date of the project. Additionally, SIPPR's Chinese name translates to English as "Sixth Design and Research Institute of Machinery Industry Co., Ltd."
sources: https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/linked-documents/49042-005-dc.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://wikileaks.org/plusd/cables/09DUSHANBE954_a.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dropbox.com/s/rl546mymjz3f15f/May%202018%20Flat%20Export%20from%20Tajikistan%20AIMS%20China%20Specific%20Projects.xlsx?dl=0 , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://mintrans.tj/ru/road-facilities/projects/remont-podhodnyh-putey-k-tonnelyu-ozodi-shar-shar, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://yws.mofcom.gov.cn/article/b/201607/20160701362517.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.tajik-gateway.org/wpe/tag/chormaghzak-tunnel-renamed-khatlon-tunnel-and-shar-shar-tunnel-renamed-ozodi-tunnel/, Media Report, including Wikileaks
location_details: This 6 km access road to the Shar Shar (Ozodi) Tunnel is located near the city of Kulyab in the Dangarinsky district of Khatlon region
GEO_notes: Norak Division is coded for this project since the Ozadi tunnel is located in this area and the access road that was funded leads to this tunnel. The location of the tunnel can be found by searching Ozodi Tunnel into google then using the source givnen in the geo-source column

title: China Eximbank provides $35 million preferential buyer’s credit for 220 kV Khujand-Ayni Power Transmission Line Project
description:
On November 25, 2010, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and the Export-Import Bank of China signed credit agreement No. N0.2010 (024) TOTAL N0. (131). In it, Eximbank agreed to provide the Tajik Ministry of Finance with a $35,055,003 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the 220 V Khujand-Ayni Power Transmission Line Project. The PBC loan carried the following terms: a 20-year maturity, 5-year grace period, and 2% interest rate (see "List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018"). Total cost of the project was $36.9 million USD.

The Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from this PBC loan to on-lend to OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” (through a subsidiary loan agreement -- No. 2010 (024) TOTAL (170) – 029 BT) at a 3% interest rate between December 15, 2010 and September 21, 2031. OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” is a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan that is responsible for the generation, transmission and distribution of electricity and thermal energy. 

The 220kV Khujand-Ayni Power Transmission Line Project involved the construction of the Ayni and Shakhristan substations and the construction of a 118km, 220kV power transmission line from Khujand to Ayni that connects the Zarafshon Valley to the unified power system through the 500kV South-North power grid. TBEA was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on July 8, 2010. The power transmission line was expected to be finished by the 20th anniversary of Tajikistan’s independence, on September 9, 2011 and the transmission line was inaugurated and put into operation on September 26, 2011. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Строительство высоковольтной линии электропередачи 220 кВ «Худжанд - Айни». The AIMS project ID is TJK/112014.

https://cis-legislation.com/document.fwx?rgn=63718, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.powerchina.cn/art/2016/11/29/art_7449_444388.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
location_details: This project involves the construction of the Ayni and Shakhristan substations and a 118km, 220kV power transmission line from Khujand to Ayni that connects the Zarafshon Valley to the unified power system through the 500kV South-North power grid.
GEO_notes: Ayni, Shahriston, Istaravshan, Ghonchi, Spitamen, Jabor Rasulov, and Ghafurov divisions were coded for this project since these are the divisions in which the powerline runs through. The location of the powerline can be found from the source provided in the geo source column (Ayni)

title: China Eximbank provides $35 million preferential buyer’s credit for 220 kV Khujand-Ayni Power Transmission Line Project
description:
On November 25, 2010, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and the Export-Import Bank of China signed credit agreement No. N0.2010 (024) TOTAL N0. (131). In it, Eximbank agreed to provide the Tajik Ministry of Finance with a $35,055,003 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the 220 V Khujand-Ayni Power Transmission Line Project. The PBC loan carried the following terms: a 20-year maturity, 5-year grace period, and 2% interest rate (see "List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018"). Total cost of the project was $36.9 million USD.

The Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from this PBC loan to on-lend to OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” (through a subsidiary loan agreement -- No. 2010 (024) TOTAL (170) – 029 BT) at a 3% interest rate between December 15, 2010 and September 21, 2031. OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” is a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan that is responsible for the generation, transmission and distribution of electricity and thermal energy. 

The 220kV Khujand-Ayni Power Transmission Line Project involved the construction of the Ayni and Shakhristan substations and the construction of a 118km, 220kV power transmission line from Khujand to Ayni that connects the Zarafshon Valley to the unified power system through the 500kV South-North power grid. TBEA was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on July 8, 2010. The power transmission line was expected to be finished by the 20th anniversary of Tajikistan’s independence, on September 9, 2011 and the transmission line was inaugurated and put into operation on September 26, 2011. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Строительство высоковольтной линии электропередачи 220 кВ «Худжанд - Айни». The AIMS project ID is TJK/112014.

title: Chinese Government provides $305,810 in grant assistance for drug trafficking seminars in Xinjiang
description:
In 2011, the Chinese Government provided grant assistance worth $305,810 to Tajikistan for seminars, as reported by the May 2018 Flat Export from Tajikistan AIMS. The AIMS project ID is TJK/112259. 

STAFF_NOTE: This was likely referencing the training courses and seminars provided in 2011 to 15 Tajik drug control officers entitled "Fight against Illicit Drug Trafficking" provided by the Ministry of Public Security of China and the XUAR Department for Public Security. The training took place in China’s Xinjiang-Uyghur Autonomous Region (XUAR).
sources: https://www.dropbox.com/s/rl546mymjz3f15f/May%202018%20Flat%20Export%20from%20Tajikistan%20AIMS%20China%20Specific%20Projects.xlsx?dl=0 , Other; https://www.asiaplus.tj/en/news/tajikistan/20111101/15-tajik-drug-control-officers-take-training-course-china, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: This project was a grant for drug trafficking seminars. These seminars were held in Xinjiang so it was coded up to country level because it took place outside of Tajikistan.

title: China Development Bank provides $15 million loan for Phase 1 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#46211, #54106, #71137)
description:
On July 4, 2009, the Export-Import Bank of China and China Development Bank (CDB) provided a $30 million USD loan for Phase 1 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project. According to Trend News Agency, the project's financing was on a 50-50 basis by the two Chinese banks to Ministry of Energy and Industry of Tajikistan. Other detailed terms of this loan are unknown. Project ID#54106 only captures the $15 million USD from China Eximbank. China Development Bank's contribution was captured in project ID#71101. Other detailed terms of this loan are unknown.

Then, in 2014, the Export-Import Bank of China provided two loans — an RMB 929,977,078 government concessional loan (GCL) (captured in project ID#46211) and a $178,969,220 USD preferential buyer’s credit loan (PBC) (captured in project ID#71137) for Phase 2 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project (for the GCL loan amount, see pg. 87 of "Program Appraisal Document on a Proposed Grant..."; for the PBC loan amount, see "Information on existing state investment projects"). Both of these loans were ratified by the Tajik Parliament on January 14, 2015. The GCL loan was contracted with the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and it carried the following terms: 25 year maturity, 11 year grace period, and 1.5% interest rate (see "РАМОЧНОЕ СОГЛАШЕНИЕ между Правительством Китайской Народной Республики и Правительством Республики Таджикистан о предоставлении Китайской Народной Республикой Республике Таджикистан льготного кредита"). The PBC loan has a 20 year maturity, 9 year grace period, and 2% interest rate (see "List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018").

The Government of Tajikistan contributed $17,443,400 USD. In total, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan contracted $331,058,220 USD of China Eximbank debt for Phase 2 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project. The Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from the GCL and the PBC loan to on-lend to Open Joint Stock Holding Company (OHSHC) “Barqi Tojik”. OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy.

The subsidiary GCL loan agreement (#TАJ 2014-028-2) was signed between Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” on December 18, 2014. It carried an interest rate of 5% and a maturity of 25 years. Its final maturity date was set to August 21, 2039. The subsidiary PBC loan agreement (#TАJ 2014-028-1) was also signed between Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” on December 18, 2014 and it carried an interest rate of 5% and a maturity of 20 years. Its final maturity date was set to June 21, 2034.

Dushanbe 2 is a combined heat and power plant (CHP) — also known as the Dushanbe-2 Thermal Power Plant (TPS-2) — that provides heat and electricity for the residents of Dushanbe. It only operates in the winter. The 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project required two phases. Phase 1 (mainly constructed between 2012-2014) installed a capacity of 100 MW, while Phase 2 (constructed between 2014-2016) installed an additional capacity of 300 MW. TBEA was the contractor responsible for implementation of both phases. CHP-2 was to be fueled by coal, with the potential to switch to gas. According to State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission of the State Council, Inner Mongolia Electric Power Survey and Design Institute Co., Ltd. was the project designer for Phase 2. According to PowerChina, Hydro Electric Power System Engineering Company was also involved in the undertaking of Phase 2 of the project.

The first phase was scheduled to be completed and put into production before the celebration of the 20th anniversary of Tajik independence in 2011 (September 9th), and the second phase was scheduled to be completed in 2013. Phase 1 of the project began on September 8, 2009 and was put into operation on November 10, 2014. Phase 2 of the project began on May 14, 2015 and was completed on December 8, 2016.

According to President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon as relayed by TBEA, the plant generates 9.6 million kWh power per day and 235 trillion Kcal heat, and provided nearly 700 stable jobs to Tajiks. 150 Tajikistan technicians went to China for training, and about 100 Tajikistan operators mastered professional know-how under the guidance of Chinese experts. According to Xinhua, the completed station met 60 percent of the power demand and enabled the restart of central heating for more than 700,000 Dushanbe residents after 15 years of suspension. The completion of the Dushanbe-2 thermal power station was also declared to be the solution to Tajikistan's long-existing issue of power shortages in winter.

This power plant is located in Dushanbe. Its exact locational coordinates are available at http://globalenergyobservatory.org/geoid/41775.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Душанбинская ТЭЦ-2. The $30 million loan from China Eximbank and China Development Bank may not have covered the full cost of Phase 1 of the project. In the Government of Tajikistan’s Aid Information Management System (AIMS), the project is referred to as "Project of construction of second in succession construction of 'TPS-2' in Dushanbe."

Some sources suggest that major delays took place after Tajikistan contracted this loan on July 4, 2009. The ceremony for the beginning of the project was clearly on September 8, 2009, but it seems project construction did not begin in earnest until 2012, when TBEA agreed to “front” $178 million for the construction of Phase 1 by borrowing directly from China Eximbank, and, in turn, the Tajik government agreed to grant TBEA exclusive rights to explore and develop gold deposits at the Eastern Duoba mine and the Upper Kumarg mine (until TBEA could recoup its investment). The Tajik government also reportedly agreed to give TBEA the rights to further mining deposits (at an unidentified location) if the profit made from the gold deposits did not cover the cost of building the power plant.

According to Kazakhstan Newsline, Tajikistan also issued a license to TBEA for the development of coal mines (see "Chinese TBEA company says Dushanbe is ready to provide its gold mines"). Another media source, Central Asia News, said that the mineral resources were to be used to compensate the costs of the company for construction of the Dushanbe-2 in the amount of $178 million USD. It also reported that the proven reserves of 3 gold mines was to be estimated 51.7 tons of gold (see "China’s TBEA may obtain license for development of another mine in Tajikistan"). Another media source, Asia-Plus reported that the license for development of the Upper Kumargh gold deposit was granted to TBEA in 2018. It also reported that in 2013, the Tajik Government gave TBEA licenses for exploration operations at both these deposits until 2017, while also exempting TBEA from customs duties and value added tax on the import of equipment (see "China's TBEA granted licenses for development of two gold deposits in Tajikistan").

It is also important to note that the Economic and Commercial Office of the Chinese Embassy reported in 2009 that TBEA was to receive mining rights in return for the project, before this exchange took place. "The Full Story Behind China's Gold Mine-Power Plant Swap in Tajikistan" article from the Diplomat is a particularly helpful source for information on this "resource-for-infrastructure" deal.

title: China Eximbank provides $53.1 million preferential buyer’s credit for Tajik Aluminum Company to launch three new plants (Linked to Project ID#71391)
description:
On July 24, 2014, Tajik Aluminum Company (TALCO) signed an EPC agreement with China National Heavy Machinery Corporation (CHMC) for the the Fluoride Salt Project. The project included the construction of three large plants in the Yovon District of Khatlon Region: a plant for the production of aluminum fluoride with annual capacity of 18,000 tons, a plant for the production of cryolite with annual capacity of 12,000 tons, and the plant for the production of sulfuric acid with annual capacity of 130,000 tons. These three plants were sometimes referred to as three separate projects: the Cryolite Project, the Aluminum Fluoride Project, and the Sulfuric Acid Project. According to "Today" on TALCO's website. 

The total cost of these projects was $126 million USD. TALCO itself will invest approximately $37 million in the plants. On November 7, 2014, to finance the rest of the project, during the Beijing APEC Summit and under the witness of Xi Jinping and President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon (see "塔铝项目贷款协议正式签订" from CNMC), the Export-Import Bank of China agreed to provide two loans to the Tajik Ministry of Finance for the Flouride Salt Project: a RMB-denominated government concessional loan (GCL) provided on highly concessional terms (20 year maturity, 11 year grace period, and 1.5% interest rate) and a $53.1 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan on highly concessional terms (2% interest rate, 20 year maturity, 9 year grace period). 

The precise face value of the GCL loan and the precise face value of the PBC loan are unknown. However, it is known that the combined value of GCL and PBC was $88.5 million, and AidData learned through correspondence with the IMF that 40% of the total debt financing from China Eximbank ($35.4 million) came from the RMB-denominated GCL and 60% of the total debt financing from China Eximbank ($53.1 million) came from the USD-denominated PBC. The loan agreements were finalized between Ministry of Finance and China Eximbank on November 7, 2014. Project ID#53755 records the PBC and Project ID#71391 records the GCL. They were then ratified by the Tajik Parliament on January 14, 2015. 

The project was located in Yovon District within Khatlon Region. Its exact locational coordinates are 38° 32' 45"N, 68° 13' 31" E. Construction was undertaken by the EPC contractor (CHMC) and these three plants were completed and officially inaugurated by Tajikistan President Emomali Rahmon on September 6, 2016. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese name of the project is 塔铝项目. The Russian name of the project is Строительство заводов по производству криолита, фтористого алюминия и серной кислоты в рамках реконструкции и модернизации ТАЛКО.

Aluminum fluoride is an inorganic compound used primarily in the production of aluminum. This colorless solid can be prepared synthetically, but also occurs naturally. Aluminum fluoride is an important additive for the production of aluminum by electrolysis. Together, with cryolite, it lowers the melting point to below 1000°C and increases the conductivity of the solution. Cryolite was historically used as an ore of aluminum, and later in the electrolytic processing of the aluminum-rich oxide ore bauxite. The difficulty of separating aluminum from oxygen in the oxide ores was overcome by the use of cryolite as a flux to dissolve the oxide minerals. Pure cryolite melts at 1012°C, and it can dissolve the aluminum oxides sufficiently to allow for the easy extraction of the aluminum by electrolysis. Substantial energy is still needed for both heating the materials and the electrolysis, but it is much more energy-efficient than melting the oxides themselves. Since natural cryolite is too rare to be used for this purpose, synthetic sodium aluminum fluoride is produced from the common mineral fluorite. Sulfuric acid has a wide range of applications, including domestic acidic drain cleaner, electrolyte in lead-acid batteries, and various cleaning agents. It is also a central substance in the chemical industry. Principal uses include mineral processing, fertilizer manufacturing, oil refining, wastewater processing, and chemical synthesis. It is widely produced with different methods, such as contact process, wet sulfuric acid process and some other methods (see "http://www.sulphuric-acid.com/sulphuric-acid-on-the-web/acid%20plants/TALCO.htm").

The Tajik Aluminum Company is one of the ten largest aluminum smelters in the world. It provides up to 70% of Tajikistan's foreign currency earnings while consuming 40% of its electrical power. TALCO is wholly owned by the Tajik Government. Tajikistan does not mine alumina, but imports the raw material through tolling arrangements.

The completion of the Dushanbe-2 thermal power station was also declared to be the solution to Tajikistan's long-existing issue of power shortages in winter.

This power plant is located in Dushanbe. Its exact locational coordinates are available at http://globalenergyobservatory.org/geoid/41775.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Душанбинская ТЭЦ-2. The $30 million loan from China Eximbank and China Development Bank may not have covered the full cost of Phase 1 of the project. In the Government of Tajikistan’s Aid Information Management System (AIMS), the project is referred to as "Project of construction of second in succession construction of 'TPS-2' in Dushanbe."

Some sources suggest that major delays took place after Tajikistan contracted this loan on July 4, 2009. The ceremony for the beginning of the project was clearly on September 8, 2009, but it seems project construction did not begin in earnest until 2012, when TBEA agreed to “front” $178 million for the construction of Phase 1 by borrowing directly from China Eximbank, and, in turn, the Tajik government agreed to grant TBEA exclusive rights to explore and develop gold deposits at the Eastern Duoba mine and the Upper Kumarg mine (until TBEA could recoup its investment). The Tajik government also reportedly agreed to give TBEA the rights to further mining deposits (at an unidentified location) if the profit made from the gold deposits did not cover the cost of building the power plant.

According to Kazakhstan Newsline, Tajikistan also issued a license to TBEA for the development of coal mines (see "Chinese TBEA company says Dushanbe is ready to provide its gold mines"). Another media source, Central Asia News, said that the mineral resources were to be used to compensate the costs of the company for construction of the Dushanbe-2 in the amount of $178 million USD. It also reported that the proven reserves of 3 gold mines was to be estimated 51.7 tons of gold (see "China’s TBEA may obtain license for development of another mine in Tajikistan"). Another media source, Asia-Plus reported that the license for development of the Upper Kumargh gold deposit was granted to TBEA in 2018. It also reported that in 2013, the Tajik Government gave TBEA licenses for exploration operations at both these deposits until 2017, while also exempting TBEA from customs duties and value added tax on the import of equipment (see "China's TBEA granted licenses for development of two gold deposits in Tajikistan").

It is also important to note that the Economic and Commercial Office of the Chinese Embassy reported in 2009 that TBEA was to receive mining rights in return for the project, before this exchange took place. "The Full Story Behind China's Gold Mine-Power Plant Swap in Tajikistan" article from the Diplomat is a particularly helpful source for information on this "resource-for-infrastructure" deal.

title: China Eximbank provides $35 million loan for Regar Substation Reconstruction Project (Linked to projects #40481, #40479, #72802, #69997)
description:
On May 20, 2013, the Export-Import Bank of China provided a $35,043,319 USD loan to the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan for the Regar Substation Reconstruction Project . The loan carried a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period from 5 to 7 years, and an interest rate of 2%. The loan agreement was ratified by the Tajik parliament in June 2013. The total cost of the project was $36.9 million USD. The Government of Tajikistan contributed $1.8 million USD to the project.

The Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from this PBC loan to on-lend — through subsidiary loan agreement Subsidiary Agreement No. TAJ-2013(22) TOTAL No.(266) BT-025, dated July 31, 2011 — to Open Joint Stock Holding Company (OHSHC) “Barqi Tojik” at a 6% interest rate between July 31, 2013 and November 21, 2033. OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy. 

This project involved the reconstruction of Regar substation, which is located near the city of Tursunzoda about 50km west of Dushanbe. Construction began on November 22, 2012. The substation was put into operation on June 1, 2016. According to Avesta Information Agency, Chinese company Tebian Electric Apparatus Stock Co., Ltd. (TBEA) implemented this project.

This project was one of many signed during the same visit of the President of Tajikistan to China from May 19th 2013 to May 20th 2013. The other projects were: Loans totaling 33 million RMB to Amonatbonk (captured in project ID#69997), a 200 million RMB grant (captured in project ID#40481), a loan to Zijin Mining for investment into the Zeravshan Gold Mine (captured in project ID#40479), loans totaling 20 million USD to Amonatbonk (captured in project ID#72802), a technical cooperation agreement, a fruit inspection protocol, and a sports cooperation agreement. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Regar substation supplies electricity to the China Eximbank-financed Talco aluminium plant (captured in project ID#53755), according to Avesta. The Russian project title is Реконструкция подстанции Регар -500 кВт.

title: Chinese Government grants $500,000 USD to Tajikistan for the Ninth Meeting of the Heads of Governments of member states of SCO
description: According to the May 2018 Flat Export from Tajikistan AIMS, the Chinese Government provided $500,000 USD in grant assistance to Tajikistan for the Ninth Meeting of the Heads of Governments of member states of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO). The AIMS project ID is TJK/112261. However, the ninth meeting of the heads of government of SCO was held in Russia in 2009, so it seems likely that this Tajikistan AIMS project may instead meant the eighth meeting of the heads of government of SCO, which was held in Tajikistan in 2008. The commitment year has therefore been coded as 2008 and flagged as year uncertain.
sources: https://www.dropbox.com/s/rl546mymjz3f15f/May%202018%20Flat%20Export%20from%20Tajikistan%20AIMS%20China%20Specific%20Projects.xlsx?dl=0 , Other; https://www.asiaplus.tj/en/news/tajikistan/politics/20181012/president-of-tajikistan-meets-with-sco-heads-of-government, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://idsa.in/strategiccomments/The9thShanghaiCooperationOrganisationSummit_MSRoy_240609, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation)
GEO_notes: Coded up to the country level since the Shanghai Cooperation Organization helps the country of Tajikistan as a whole and no individual district in particular

title: China-funded Takuriabu Anti-drug Branch office building
description: On March 18, 2016, Yue Bin, the ambassador to Tajikistan, attended the completion handover ceremony of the office building of the China-funded Takuriabu Anti-drug Branch office building. The project was funded by Ministry of Public Security of China and implemented by China Jing'an Import & Export Corporation. The office building aided by the Chinese side is a three-story brick-concrete structure with a construction area of ​​more than 1,000 square meters, including offices, equipment rooms, interrogation rooms, lounges.
sources: http://tj.chineseembassy.org/chn/sbgx/t1348927.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.xinhuanet.com/world/2016-03/19/c_128814017.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: Coded the Kulob District since one fo the articles given stated that the "office building project is located in Kulyab". Found the city on google maps and was able to find that is the district as well which i coded using QGIS and GeoJSON

title: Chinese Government grants $2.7 million worth of equipment to the Tajik Drug Control Agency
description: On November 23, 2007, China donated mobile drug testing equipment worthing $2,739,726 to the Drug Control Agency of Tajikistan. The equipment was designed to detect illicit substances in vehicles and containers. The Development Partners Profile 2012 calls this project 'Mobile inspection and observation complex.' STAFF_NOTE: The BBC listed the total value of the equipment as $4 million. But the Flat Export of AIMS Tajikistan as of May 2018 reported a 'Mobile inspection-examination complex' project funded by the Chinese government for $2,739,726, which is the amount captured in this project.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCCA00020071123e3bn0012x&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dropbox.com/s/rl546mymjz3f15f/May%202018%20Flat%20Export%20from%20Tajikistan%20AIMS%20China%20Specific%20Projects.xlsx?dl=0 , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.tj.undp.org/content/dam/tajikistan/docs/library/UNDP_TJK_DPP_2012_Eng.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 546 million government concessional loan for 500 kV Power Transmission Lines from Rogun Hydropower Plant to Dushanbe Project
description:
On September 1, 2017, the Export–Import Bank of China and the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed an RMB 546,032,200 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the 500 kV Power Transmission Lines from Rogun Hydropower Plant to Dushanbe Project. According to Avesta, the loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 25 years and 1.5% interest rate per annum. The loan agreement was ratified by the Tajik parliament in December 2017.

The Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from this PBC loan to on-lend -- through subsidiary loan agreement No. TAJ-2017-02 (BT-039), dated 29.12.2017 -- to Open Joint Stock Holding Company (OHSHC) “Barqi Tojik” at a 3% interest rate between December 29, 2017 and August 21, 2042. As of OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy. 

The project involved the construction of two 500 kV, high voltage power transmission lines with a length of approximately 100 km from the Rogun hydropower plant in the town of Obi Garm (within the district of Rogun) to Dushanbe. The Dushanbe-Obigarm project was designed to improve reliability and quantity of supplied energy and reduce losses in the Rasht Valley of Tajikistan, where the Nurabad, Rasht, Tajikabad, Tavildara and Lakhsh districts are located. The Dushanbe-Obi Garm 500-kV power transmission line would also help increase the export of Tajik electricity to neighboring countries. The connection between the power grids of Districts of Republican Subordination and the southern power grid would also be improved. According to the 03/29/2019 Sputnik article, the transmission lines were to pass through the territories of Faizabad, Vahdat, Rudaki and Varzob. A substation, Dushanbe-500 substation, was also to be constructed as part of the project. 

Chinese company Tebian Electric Apparatus Stock Co., Ltd. (TBEA) was contracted to implement the project. In addition, according to PowerChina, Hubei Engineering Company Engineering Construction Company was involved in the project's implementation. Construction began on October 1, 2017. The project was completed and put into operation on November 16, 2018. 

STAFF_NOTE: This project is also known as the 500-kV transmission line Dushanbe-Obi Garm Project or the Project "Reconstruction and construction of 500 kV power transmission line in the republican subordination." The Russian project title is Линия электропередачи 500 кВ «Душанбе-Рогун» or  проекта реконструкции высоковольтной 500-киловольтной линии электропередачи районов республиканского подчинения. Note that Rogun Hydropower Plant is sometimes also referred to as Roghun Hydropower Plant. Additionally, some sources, including press releases from Tajik government ministries, denominated the loan amount in US dollars, as $79 million USD. However, under Eximbank's policy, the government concessional l loan was always denominated in Chinese Yuan.

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 546 million government concessional loan for 500 kV Power Transmission Lines from Rogun Hydropower Plant to Dushanbe Project
description:
On September 1, 2017, the Export–Import Bank of China and the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed an RMB 546,032,200 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the 500 kV Power Transmission Lines from Rogun Hydropower Plant to Dushanbe Project. According to Avesta, the loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 25 years and 1.5% interest rate per annum. The loan agreement was ratified by the Tajik parliament in December 2017.

The Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from this PBC loan to on-lend -- through subsidiary loan agreement No. TAJ-2017-02 (BT-039), dated 29.12.2017 -- to Open Joint Stock Holding Company (OHSHC) “Barqi Tojik” at a 3% interest rate between December 29, 2017 and August 21, 2042. As of OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy. 

The project involved the construction of two 500 kV, high voltage power transmission lines with a length of approximately 100 km from the Rogun hydropower plant in the town of Obi Garm (within the district of Rogun) to Dushanbe. The Dushanbe-Obigarm project was designed to improve reliability and quantity of supplied energy and reduce losses in the Rasht Valley of Tajikistan, where the Nurabad, Rasht, Tajikabad, Tavildara and Lakhsh districts are located. The Dushanbe-Obi Garm 500-kV power transmission line would also help increase the export of Tajik electricity to neighboring countries. The connection between the power grids of Districts of Republican Subordination and the southern power grid would also be improved. According to the 03/29/2019 Sputnik article, the transmission lines were to pass through the territories of Faizabad, Vahdat, Rudaki and Varzob. A substation, Dushanbe-500 substation, was also to be constructed as part of the project. 

Chinese company Tebian Electric Apparatus Stock Co., Ltd. (TBEA) was contracted to implement the project. In addition, according to PowerChina, Hubei Engineering Company Engineering Construction Company was involved in the project's implementation. Construction began on October 1, 2017. The project was completed and put into operation on November 16, 2018. 

STAFF_NOTE: This project is also known as the 500-kV transmission line Dushanbe-Obi Garm Project or the Project "Reconstruction and construction of 500 kV power transmission line in the republican subordination." The Russian project title is Линия электропередачи 500 кВ «Душанбе-Рогун» or  проекта реконструкции высоковольтной 500-киловольтной линии электропередачи районов республиканского подчинения. Note that Rogun Hydropower Plant is sometimes also referred to as Roghun Hydropower Plant. Additionally, some sources, including press releases from Tajik government ministries, denominated the loan amount in US dollars, as $79 million USD. However, under Eximbank's policy, the government concessional l loan was always denominated in Chinese Yuan.

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 1.5 billion grant for Government Complex and Parliamentary Complex Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#71727)
description: On August 31, 2017, the Chinese Government agreed to provide Tajikistan with a RMB 1.5 billion grant (approx. $230 million USD) to finance the construction of a new parliament and government complex. The main building of the parliamentary complex was to be 49.7 meters high, for a total area of 42,874 square meters. The government complex involved the construction of a 15-story building and two 13-story buildings, for a total area of 10.27 hectares. The parliament complex was to be built in Dushanbe on Rudaki Avenue, and the government complex was to be built in downtown Dushanbe on Rudaki Avenue and Ismoili Somoni Avenue. On October 13, 2018, President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon and Premier of the State Council of the People's Republic of China Li Keqiang participated in a groundbreaking ceremony for the project. On June 15, 2019, Xi Jinping and President Rahmon attended a ceremony to unveil the construction models of the buildings after their talks in Dushanbe. It was expected, in September 2018, that the construction would be completed in 2020. In 2018, the Chinese Government provided an additional RMB 900 million in funding for the preparation and implementation of this project. For this project, see linked project ID#71727.

title: CNMC provides $120 million loan to refinance 2012 loan from ICBC (Macau) (Linked to Project ID#54361, #70174, #70220, #70319, #70354, #70367, #70407, #70430)
description:
On May 24, 2012, China Nonferrous Metals International Mining Co. Ltd (CNMIM) provided a secured loan facility on commercial terms to Kryso Resources PLC — the mineral exploration and development company developing the Pakrut Gold Project —  for $10 million and RMB 530 million to finance the development of the Pakrut Gold Project (see linked Project ID#70174 and #70319). Then, on June 19, 2014, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Macau) Limited provided a $120 million term loan facility to China Nonferrous Mining Group for the Pakrut Gold Project (see linked Project ID#70220).

Then, on May 6, 2016, China Nonferrous Mining Group obtained a $120 million from CNMC International Capitals Company Limited (“CNMC”)— an associate of China Nonferrous Metals International Mining Co. Ltd (CNMIM) — refinancing the loan facility that it contracted with ICBC on June 19, 2014 for the Pakrut Gold Project. This loan from CNMC was repayable on December 31, 2018 and included an annual fixed interest rate of 4% on the amount drawn down, payable in arrears.

LLC Pakrut, a mine that is 100% owned by Kryso Resources Ltd, was first established in 2003 and it operates the Pakrut deposit located on the southern slope of the Gissar range, 107 km from the city of Dushanbe. The geological exploration at Pakrut deposit started in 2004. The pre-gold reserves at the deposit, approved by the State Reserves Committee (CRC) of the Republic of Tajikistan, were 28.1 tons. The reserves of Pakrut gold mine are currently estimated to be 100 tons. In November 2011, the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan issued a mining licence to LLC Pakrut. Construction started in September 2012. The project went into production on June 5, 2016. In February 2017, high levels of snowfall caused significant damage to the facilities and equipment, and interrupted the construction, which was restarted in the second half of 2017. All construction work was expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2018 and production was expected to be recommenced in April 2018.

This mining project is located in Vahdat District, Republic of Tajikistan, about 80 km northeast (“NE”) in a straight line (112 km by road) from Dushanbe, the country’s capital city. It sits on the on the southern slope of the Gissar range. More detailed locational information can be found at http://www.cnfgold.com/Managed/Resources/docs/Downloads/srk_report.pdf.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is "塔吉克斯坦帕克鲁特金矿." As this is a loan refinancing, the transaction value of the loan is not recorded to prevent overcounting.

title: Chinese Government forgives $6.5 million loan to Tajikistan
description: In 2000, the Chinese Government forgave a $6.5 million USD loan to Tajikistan (see pg.10 of 'INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND REPUBLIC OF TAJIKISTAN Staff Report for the 2006 Article IV Consultation'). STAFF_NOTE: The IMF's language states that the Tajikistan's external debt from China was converted into a grant. Additionally, little is known about the loan that was forgiven, but it was mostly likely made prior to the year 2000.

title: China Eximbank provides $55.2 million preferential buyer's credit for 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project (Linked to Project ID#39644, #70910)
description:
In March 2006, the Government of Tajikistan and the Export-Import Bank of China signed a MoU for projects proposed by Tajikistan. Later, on December 16, 2006, the Export-Import Bank of China provided a $58,228,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement with the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan for the 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project. The loan terms carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period of 5 to 7 years, and an interest rate of 2% (see the cited resource"List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018"). 

The Government of Tajikistan used nearly all of the proceeds from this loan ($55,227,590, according to pg. 87 of "Tajikistan Power Utility Financial Recovery Program") to on-lend (through subsidiary loan agreement No. BLA06016) to Open Joint Stock Holding Company (OHSHC) “Barqi Tojik” at a 3% interest rate between December 16, 2006 and June 21, 2026. As of December 31, 2018, $520,774 USD was outstanding. OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy (pg. 15 of "Consolidated..."). 

The initial value of the project was $58.1 million USD. The Government of Tajikistan contributed $2.9 million USD to the project. Tebian Electric Apparatus Stock (TBEA) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The project was launched in May 2006. The transmission line was planned to be commissioned by the end of December 2007, but the inclusion of the construction of an additional internal 110 kV transmission line from the Khatlon substation to the Bokhtar substation postponed the start date. The Lolazor-Khatlon transmission line was commissioned on June 25, 2008.

The purpose of this project was to construct a 90 km, 220 kV electricity transmission line between Dangara and Kulab. This would connect the southern region to the national grid. The new power transmission line would improve the power supply in the south of the Khatlon region, and create a more stable power supply. The Lolazor-Khatlon line had a capacity of approximately 4 billion kWh of electricity a year. The project was to provide the Khatlon region with electricity from the Sangtuda 1 and 2 hydroelectric power plants, and allow for the export of electricity to Afghanistan. 

The project is linked to project ID#70910, which captured a $51 million funding from Eximbank in 2009 for both the 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project and a 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line Project (The original financing of the 500 kV project in 2006 was captured in project ID#39644).

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is высоковольтных линий электропередач 500 кВ «Юг – Север» и 220 кВ «Лолазор –Хатлон». Some official sources identify $55,227,590 as the face value of the loan. 

Additionally, this loan was coded as export buyer's credits after much consideration. The "China as an Emerging Donor..." article indicated that China offered PBCs, Tajikistan made proposals for projects, and this project was selected. An Export-Import Bank article, although it does not explicitly name this project as a loan, states that Eximbank and Tajikistan signed preferential export buyer’s credit agreements in June 2006, close to the timeframe of the commitment of financing for this project. Because of this evidence, this loan was considered a PBC and coded as such.

title: China opens Confucius Institute at Tajikistan National University
description: In 2008, Xinjiang Normal University helped established a Confucius Institute at Tajikistan's Nationality University. The Institute has operated for over 10 years now, growing from 200 students to over 4,000 students. The Institute has offered language training, cultural exchanges, and instrument training to the students.
sources: http://english.hanban.org/node_10689.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-10/12/c_137528152.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: Coded the Rudaki District (capital) since that is where the university is. Was able to locate the school and found the road it was on which allowed me to code teh correct Rudaki District

title: Chinese Government commits a RMB 5 million interest-free loan to Tajikistan
description: On April 9, 2001, the Chinese Government and the Government of Tajikistan signed an RMB 5 million interest-free loan agreement. The agreement was signed between the delegations from the Tajikistan ministry for trade and economy and the Chinese ministry for foreign trade and economic cooperation. It is not known how the proceeds of this loan were used.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=tass000020010715dx49009o0&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: Coded to the country level since the interest free loan is beneficial to the country as whole.

title: Chinese Government donates TV and FM transmitters worth $684,931 to Tajikistan
description: In 2008, the Chinese Government donated broadcasting equipment worth $684,931 to Tajikistan, as reported in the May 2018 Flat Export from Tajikistan AIMS. The AIMS project ID is TJK/082179. According to Development Partner Profiles 2012, the broadcasting equipment was specifically TV and FM transmitters. STAFF_NOTE: 'Year uncertain' box was checked because it is not confirmed that the donation of this equipment was committed in 2008. While 'Development Partner Profiles 2012' does not explain much, the timeframe, type of flow, and what was being donated showed that this was the same project captured by AIMS.

title: Chinese Embassy funded Gulafshon Women's Sewing Training and Production Center in Dushanbe (Linked to project ID#53594, #53591, #53587 #71883, #71881)
description:
In June 2014, the Chinese Embassy of Tajikistan helped to establish a sewing training center "Gulafshon" in Dushanbe and employs 60 women. The center is located in a small three-story building on Zalozi Street, Maslozhelkomupo District, Dushanbe, the capital of Tajikistan. 

On June 4, 2014, Zhao Xiangrong, the Chinese Ambassador to Tajikistan, attended the inauguration ceremony of the “Gulafushang” Women's Sewing Training Production Center. Others attending included Mr. Ratibov, Vice Chairman of the People’s Democratic Party of the People’s Republic of China, Kurbova, Vice Mayor of Dushanbe, Mrs. Sun Wei, the wife of the Political Counselor of the Embassy, and more than 100 representatives from the relevant departments of the tower and local women and children. Project ID#71883 captured the sewing center named "Gurdaston" in Dushanbe. Project ID#71881 captured the sewing center in the Dzhami District, Khatlon.

Chinese Embassy also funded other differenct Women’s Sewing Training and Production Center in Tajikistan. Project ID#53594 captured the sewing center in Danghara. Project ID#53591 captured the sewing center in Vakhsh District, Khatlon. Project ID#53587 captured the sewing center in Sino District, Dushanbe.

STAFF_NOTE: Transaction amount was not found.

GEO_notes: A sewing center was opened in Dushanbe, which is Rudaki District. This was coded using QGIS.

title: CNMIM provides $19.1 million loan to China Nonferrous Mining Group for working capital purposes related to the Pakrut Gold Project (Linked to Project ID#54361, #70174, #70220, #70319, #70324, #70367, #70407, #70430)
description:
On May 24, 2012, China Nonferrous Metals International Mining Co. Ltd (CNMIM) provided a secured loan facility on commercial terms to Kryso Resources PLC — the mineral exploration and development company developing the Pakrut Gold Project — for $10 million and RMB 530 million to finance the development of the Pakrut Gold Project (see linked Project ID#70174 and #70319). Then, on June 19, 2014, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Macau) Limited provided a $120 million term loan facility to China Nonferrous Mining Group for the Pakrut Gold Project (see linked Project ID#70220).  Then, on May 6, 2016, China Nonferrous Mining Group obtained a loan facility $120 million from CNMC International Capitals Company Limited (“CNMC”)— an associate of CNMIM — to refinance the loan facility that it contracted with Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Macau) Limited on June 19, 2014 for the Pakrut Gold Project (see linked Project ID#70324).

On June 27, 2016 the China Nonferrous Mining Group obtained another loan, worth $19,114,809, from CNMIM for working capital purposes related to the Pakrut Gold Project (see "Interim Results" published on September 30, 2016).

LLC Pakrut, a mine that is 100% owned by Kryso Resources Ltd, was first established in 2003 and it operates the Pakrut deposit located on the southern slope of the Gissar range, 107 km from the city of Dushanbe. The geological exploration at Pakrut deposit started in 2004. The pre-gold reserves at the deposit, approved by the State Reserves Committee (CRC) of the Republic of Tajikistan, were 28.1 tons. The reserves of Pakrut gold mine are currently estimated to be 100 tons. In November 2011, the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan issued a mining licence to LLC Pakrut. Construction started in September 2012. The project went into production on June 5, 2016. In February 2017, high levels of snowfall caused significant damage to the facilities and equipment, and interrupted the construction, which was restarted in the second half of 2017. All construction work was expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2018 and production was expected to be recommenced in April 2018.

This mining project is located in Vahdat District, Republic of Tajikistan, about 80 km northeast (“NE”) in a straight line (112 km by road) from Dushanbe, the country’s capital city. It sits on the southern slope of the Gissar range. More detailed locational information can be found at http://www.cnfgold.com/Managed/Resources/docs/Downloads/srk_report.pdf.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is "塔吉克斯坦帕克鲁特金矿."

title: Chinese Government provides a RMB 72.98 million grant for the construction of two Nurek schools
description: In 2013, the Chinese government decided to assist two schools in Tajikistan. Yanjian Group successfully won the bid for this project. The two schools in Nurek, Tajikistan, were funded by the Chinese government. The project cost was 72.98 million yuan. The project is located in Nurek City, Tajikistan. 22-Class schools are located in the center of Nurek City, and 11-Class schools are located in the suburbs of Nurek City. The project occupies a total area of 4.28 hectares, with a construction area of 9508 square meters, and can accommodate 1124 students to school at the same time. The project started on June 6, 2014 and was successfully completed on December 6, 2015. On April 27, 2016, the completion ceremony for two Nurek schools, constructed with Chinese Government assistance, was held. President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon and Chinese Ambassador to Tajikistan Yue Bin of Tajikistan attended. The advanced design and facilities of the two Nurek schools was expected to provide a good learning environment for thousands of Tajik students. The schools featured classrooms, canteens and stadiums, according to the embassy.
sources: http://tj.chineseembassy.org/chn/sbgx/t1358988.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://english.yanjian.com.cn/Article/ShowArticle.asp?ArticleID=158, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://news.iqilu.com/shandong/kejiaoshehui/20180510/3911738.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks
location_details: The project is located in Nurek City, Tajikistan.
GEO_notes: Coded the Norak District. Was not able tofind the exact schools, but the title, description and location details all gave Nurek City as the location whcih is a city in the Norak district of Tajikistan.

title: China Eximbank provides $15 million loan for Phase 1 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project (Linked to Project ID #46211, #71101, #71137)
description:
On July 4, 2009, the Export-Import Bank of China and China Development Bank (CDB) provided a $30 million USD loan for Phase 1 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project. According to Trend News Agency, the project's financing was on a 50-50 basis by the two Chinese banks to Ministry of Energy and Industry of Tajikistan. Other detailed terms of this loan are unknown. Project ID#54106 only captures the $15 million USD from China Eximbank. China Development Bank's contribution was captured in project ID#71101. Other detailed terms of this loan are unknown.

Then, in 2014, the Export-Import Bank of China provided two loans — an RMB 929,977,078 government concessional loan (GCL) (captured in project ID#46211) and a $178,969,220 USD preferential buyer’s credit loan (PBC) (captured in project ID#71137) for Phase 2 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project (for the GCL loan amount, see pg. 87 of "Program Appraisal Document on a Proposed Grant..."; for the PBC loan amount, see "Information on existing state investment projects"). Both of these loans were ratified by the Tajik Parliament on January 14, 2015. The GCL loan was contracted with the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and it carried the following terms: 25 year maturity, 11 year grace period, and 1.5% interest rate (see "РАМОЧНОЕ СОГЛАШЕНИЕ между Правительством Китайской Народной Республики и Правительством Республики Таджикистан о предоставлении Китайской Народной Республикой Республике Таджикистан льготного кредита"). The PBC loan has a 20 year maturity, 9 year grace period, and 2% interest rate (see "List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018"). 

The Government of Tajikistan contributed $17,443,400 USD. In total, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan contracted $331,058,220 USD of China Eximbank debt for Phase 2 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project. The Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from the GCL and the PBC loan to on-lend to Open Joint Stock Holding Company (OHSHC) “Barqi Tojik”. OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy.

The subsidiary GCL loan agreement (#TАJ 2014-028-2) was signed between Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” on December 18, 2014. It carried an interest rate of 5% and a maturity of 25 years. Its final maturity date was set to August 21, 2039. The subsidiary PBC loan agreement (#TАJ 2014-028-1) was also signed between Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” on December 18, 2014 and it carried an interest rate of 5% and a maturity of 20 years. Its final maturity date was set to June 21, 2034. 

Dushanbe 2 is a combined heat and power plant (CHP) — also known as the Dushanbe-2 Thermal Power Plant (TPS-2) — that provides heat and electricity for the residents of Dushanbe. It only operates in the winter. The 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project required two phases. Phase 1 (mainly constructed between 2012-2014) installed a capacity of 100 MW, while Phase 2 (constructed between 2014-2016) installed an additional capacity of 300 MW. TBEA was the contractor responsible for implementation of both phases. CHP-2 was to be fueled by coal, with the potential to switch to gas. According to State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission of the State Council, Inner Mongolia Electric Power Survey and Design Institute Co., Ltd. was the project designer for Phase 2. According to PowerChina, Hydro Electric Power System Engineering Company was also involved in the undertaking of Phase 2 of the project.

The first phase was scheduled to be completed and put into production before the celebration of the 20th anniversary of Tajik independence in 2011 (September 9th), and the second phase was scheduled to be completed in 2013. Phase 1 of the project began on September 8, 2009 and was put into operation on November 10, 2014. Phase 2 of the project began on May 14, 2015 and was completed on December 8, 2016.

According to President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon as relayed by TBEA, the plant generates 9.6 million kWh power per day and 235 trillion Kcal heat, and provided nearly 700 stable jobs to Tajiks. 150 Tajikistan technicians went to China for training, and about 100 Tajikistan operators mastered professional know-how under the guidance of Chinese experts. According to Xinhua, the completed station met 60 percent of the power demand and enabled the restart of central heating for more than 700,000 Dushanbe residents after 15 years of suspension. The completion of the Dushanbe-2 thermal power station was also declared to be the solution to Tajikistan's long-existing issue of power shortages in winter.

This power plant is located in Dushanbe. Its exact locational coordinates are available at http://globalenergyobservatory.org/geoid/41775.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Душанбинская ТЭЦ-2. The $30 million loan from China Eximbank and China Development Bank may not have covered the full cost of Phase 1 of the project. In the Government of Tajikistan’s Aid Information Management System (AIMS), the project is referred to as "Project of construction of second in succession construction of 'TPS-2' in Dushanbe." 

Some sources suggest that major delays took place after Tajikistan contracted this loan on July 4, 2009. The ceremony for the beginning of the project was clearly on September 8, 2009, but it seems project construction did not begin in earnest until 2012, when TBEA agreed to “front” $178 million for the construction of Phase 1 by borrowing directly from China Eximbank, and, in turn, the Tajik government agreed to grant TBEA exclusive rights to explore and develop gold deposits at the Eastern Duoba mine and the Upper Kumarg mine (until TBEA could recoup its investment). The Tajik government also reportedly agreed to give TBEA the rights to further mining deposits (at an unidentified location) if the profit made from the gold deposits did not cover the cost of building the power plant.

According to Kazakhstan Newsline, Tajikistan also issued a license to TBEA for the development of coal mines (see "Chinese TBEA company says Dushanbe is ready to provide its gold mines"). Another media source, Central Asia News, said that the mineral resources were to be used to compensate the costs of the company for construction of the Dushanbe-2 in the amount of $178 million USD. It also reported that the proven reserves of 3 gold mines was to be estimated 51.7 tons of gold (see "China’s TBEA may obtain license for development of another mine in Tajikistan"). Another media source, Asia-Plus reported that the license for development of the Upper Kumargh gold deposit was granted to TBEA in 2018. It also reported that in 2013, the Tajik Government gave TBEA licenses for exploration operations at both these deposits until 2017, while also exempting TBEA from customs duties and value added tax on the import of equipment (see "China's TBEA granted licenses for development of two gold deposits in Tajikistan").

It is also important to note that the Economic and Commercial Office of the Chinese Embassy reported in 2009 that TBEA was to receive mining rights in return for the project, before this exchange took place. "The Full Story Behind China's Gold Mine-Power Plant Swap in Tajikistan" article from the Diplomat is a particularly helpful source for information on this "resource-for-infrastructure" deal.

title: China Development Bank funds 15 employees of the State Savings Bank of Tajikistan 'Amonatbonk' for Chinese university education
description:
After 2009, China Development Bank (CDB) provided funds so that 15 employees of the State Savings Bank of the Republic of Tajikistan "Amonatbonk" could enter into Chinese universities to learn the Chinese language. By November 2019, 12 selected employees had graduated, while three employees, specialists at the Head Office of Bank, were studying at the International Education College of Shandong University of Jinan (see "Вохӯрии Раиси Раёсати БДА ҶТ «Амонатбонк» бо Роҳбари Бонки давлатии Рушди Хитой дар Ҷумҳурии Тоҷикистон ва Ўзбекистон" and pg. 36-37 of English half of "Amonatbonk 2014 Annual Report"). The value of the education is unknown.

STAFF_NOTE: "Year uncertain" was selected because it is unknown exactly when this program began, only that it began "since 2009" and was active before November 2019. It appears that the 3 employees at Shandong University were agreed upon in 2014 (see pg. 36-37 of English half of "Amonatbonk 2014 Annual Report").
sources: https://amonatbonk.tj/tj/about/news/5381/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.amonatbonk.tj/upload/iblock/11f/annualreport20141.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: Employees of the State Savings Bank were part of a program to learn Chinese. This project enabled them to go to Chinese universities. It was coded up to country level because this project took place out of Tajikistan.

title: Chinese Government provides US$2 million food aid to victims of natural disasters in Tajikistan
description: In November 2002, the Chinese Government provided humanitarian food aid to the victims of natural disasters in Tajikistan. The aid included 15 tons of rice, 10 tons of sugar and 2,000 barrels of edible oil (5 liters of oil per barrel). The value of the food aid is US$2 million. STAFF_NOTE: This project is not to be confused with food aid provided by China in March 2003 (project ID#40220).
sources: http://tj.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/jmxw/200305/20030500093181.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://reliefweb.int/report/tajikistan/china-gives-tajikistan-2-million-dollars-food-aid, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: Coded to the country level since the food aid would be distributed throughout the country and a more specific district could not be found.

title: Chinese Academy of Sciences builds Dushanbe Research Center for Ecology and Environment of Central Asia
description:
On September 13, 2014, Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) signed an agreement on scientific cooperation with Academy of Sciences of Tajikistan on the construction of Tajik branch of the Dushanbe Research Center for Ecology and Environment of Central Asia, as an official NGO. The center was jointly built by CAS and the Tajik Academy of Sciences, and dealt with the ecological environment, geology, and physics. The opening ceremony of the center was held on August 29, 2016. The main objective of the center is to "conduct fundamental and applied research in the field of natural Sciences". This center was the first joint scientific institution between Tajikistan and China.

STAFF_NOTE: The project is known in Chinese as "中国科学院中亚生态与环境研究中心塔吉克斯坦分中心". According to the Research Center for Ecology and Environment of Central Asia, CAS provided $2 million dollars in research equipment to joint laboratories in Central Asia, including a joint laboratory for geology and mineralogy in Tajikistan, which is probably this. However, if it's not clear if each lab received $2 million dollars in equipment, or if the combined value of equipment spread across the three labs was $2 million, so the coder did not code a transaction amount.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=ASIPLU0020160831ec8v00008&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.sciencenet.cn/htmlnews/2016/8/354766.shtm, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://tj.china-embassy.org/chn/xwdt/t1546896.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.rceeca.com/Russian/Article.html?type=ptjs, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
GEO_notes: Coded the Rudaki District (capital). Both the description and location_details gave Dushanbe as the location. A given article aslo mentioned the Academy of Sciences as the location for the Dushanbe Research Center for Ecology and Environment of Central Asia. I found the location on google maps of the Acamdey of Science and was able to code the correct Rudaki District.

title: China Donates $1,500 to Give 2870 Textbooks to Two Schools in Tajikistan
description: In August 2004, The Chinese embassy in Tajikistan donated 2,870 textbooks in Russian to two secondary schools in Dushanbe. 2,870 textbooks worth 1,500 dollars had been given to school number 51 and the presidential school.

title: China Eximbank provides $51 million preferential buyer’s credit to provide additional support to 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line Project and 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project (Linked to Project ID#39984 and #39644)
description:
On May 15, 2009, the Export-Import Bank of China and Government of Tajikistan signed a credit agreement, according to the Tajikistan Ministry of Finance. China Eximbank agreed to provide a $51,000,000 USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan to the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan (see pg. 37 of "Consolidated financial statements..."). This loan was intended to provide additional financing to the 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line Project and 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project. Both of these projects were supported by Export-Import Bank loans approved in 2006 (see Project ID#39984 and Project ID#39644). The terms of this PBC loan are unknown.

However, it is known that the Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from this PBC loan to on-lend “Barqi Tojik” at a 3% interest rate between May 29, 2007 and December 21, 2028. As of December 31, 2018, $480,910 USD was outstanding. OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy (pg. 15 of "Consolidated..."). 

The purpose of the 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line Project was to construct a 500 kV electricity transmission line that would connect the northern Sughd region to the national grid. According to Xinhua, the project also intended to realize the effective dispatching of electricity between Dushanbe and Khujand, completely solve the problem of power shortage in the south during the dry season in winter, build the transmission channel for the implementation of the Tajik Hydropower Strategy, improve the safety, stability, and reliability of the power grid, and reduce the loss of electricity through transmission from 14% to 3.2%. 

According to Asia-Plus, the purpose of the 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project was to construct a 90 km, 220 kV electricity transmission line between Dangara and Kulab. This would connect the southern region to the national grid. According to President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon, relayed by Asia-Plus, the new power transmission line would improve the power supply in the south of the Khatlon region, and create a more stable power supply. The Lolazor-Khatlon line had a capacity of approximately 4 billion kWh of electricity a year, according to Asia-Plus. The project was to provide the Khatlon region with electricity from the Sangtuda 1 and 2 hydroelectric power plants, and allow for the export of electricity to Afghanistan.

Tebian Electric Apparatus Stock (TBEA) was the contractor responsible for the implementation of both projects (see pg. 14 of "China as an Emerging Donor..."). The North-South transmission line has been operational since November 29, 2009 (see pg. 11 of "BRI in Central Asia: Energy Connectivity Projects").  According to Asia-Plus, the Lolazor-Khatlon transmission line has been operational since June 25, 2008. 

The project is linked to previous fundings of a 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line project (captured in project ID#39644) and a 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project (captured in project ID#39984) in 2006.

STAFF_NOTE: The document "Consolidated financial statements..." states the agreement for the loan was May 29, 2007, but several official sources gave May 15, 2009. It was assumed that the later was correct.
sources: http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/975041566983244120/pdf/Tajikistan-Nurek-Hydropower-Rehabilitation-Project-Phase-I-Barki-Tajik-Entity-Audit-report-for-the-year-ended-December-31-2018.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.ifri.org/sites/default/files/atoms/files/ifrichinacentralasiakassenovaengjanuary2008.pdf, Academic Journal Article; http://www.osce-academy.net/upload/file/CADGAT_22_BRI_Energy.docx, Academic Journal Article; http://minfin.tj/index.php?newsid=110 , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://jjckb.xinhuanet.com/cjxw/2009-12/01/content_194720.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/877071468303575509/pdf/891840NWP0P14700TJK0NOTE60final0web.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/35672bfe3ltwhlr/Ministry%20of%20Finance%20of%20the%20Republic%20of%20Tajikistan.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: This project was coded up to Khatlon (an ADM1) because there was only one endpoint given: Lolazor. The other name listed is the province. Lolazor is located in Danghara District, which is located in Khatlon Province. Additonally, there was no map so I had to code up.

title: CNMIM provides RMB 530 million loan for Pakrut Gold Project (Linked to Project ID#54361, #70174, #70220, #70324, #70354, #70367, #70407, #70430)
description:
On May 24, 2012, China Nonferrous Metals International Mining Co. Ltd (CNMIM) and Kryso Resources PLC signed a Shareholder Loan Agreement for a loan made on commercial terms to Kryso Resources PLC — the mineral exploration and development company developing the Pakrut Gold Project. 

The secured loan facility consisted of two tranches; a tranche for RMB 530 million and a tranche for $10 million USD. It was to be used exclusively for the design, construction, operation and administration of the Pakrut Gold Project, including operating costs, capital expenditure, and general working capital. The RMB tranche was disbursed by CNMIM entering into contracts with third parties on behalf of Kryso or LLC Pakrut as their agent and transferring amounts to the bank accounts of such parties. The term of the loan went from the date of the first advance until May 31, 2017. The annual fixed interest rate was 9% for both tranches and a management fee at 0.5% on the total amount of the loan was paid within 30 days of the first advance. Default interest of 13.5% per annum was payable on overdue amounts on the tranches. The Group was to repay all amounts of principal and interest in respect in USD at the fixed exchange rate of $1 USD to 6.30 RMB. The repayment dates were May 31, 2015, November 11, 2015, May 31, 2016, November 11, 2016, and May 31, 2017 for both tranches. November 30, 2014 was the end of the loan availability period. Kryso had drawn down RMB 384,802,696 (equivalent to $61,079,793 USD at the fixed repayment exchange rate) under the RMB tranche. Kryso pledged its 100% equity interest in LLC Pakrut to CNMIM as security for repayment of the loan (see pg.45-46 of "Annual Report and Financial Statements for the Year Ended 31 December 2015").

This project only captures the RMB tranche of the loan facility. For the USD tranche, please see Project ID #70174.

LLC Pakrut, a mine that is 100% owned by Kryso Resources Ltd, operates the Pakrut deposit located on the southern slope of the Gissar range, 112 km from the city of Dushanbe (see "Final Results and Notice of AGM"). Relevant geological exploration at the Pakrut deposit began in 2004 (see pp.iii "Independent Technical Report of the Pakrut Gold Project  in Vahdat Region, Republic of Tajikistan. According to the 2018 report published on Bloomberg, in November 2011, the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan issued a mining license to LLC Pakrut. 

According to SRK, at a gold cut-off of 1.0 g/t, the JORC Code compliant Proved Ore Reserves for Pakrut were estimated at 15,721 thousand tonnes (“kt”) averaging 3.1 g/t of gold. The JORC Code compliant Probable Ore Reserves were estimated at 2,787 kt averaging 2.5 g/t of gold. Construction started in September 2012. The project went into production on June 5, 2016. In February 2017, high levels of snowfall caused significant damage to the facilities and equipment, and interrupted the construction, which was restarted in the second half of 2017. All construction work was expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2018 and production was expected to be recommenced in April 2018. 

This mining project is located in Vahdat District, Republic of Tajikistan, about 80 km northeast (“NE”) in a straight line (112 km by road) from Dushanbe, the country’s capital city. It sits on the southern slope of the Gissar range. More detailed locational information can be found at http://www.cnfgold.com/Managed/Resources/docs/Downloads/srk_report.pdf.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is "塔吉克斯坦帕克鲁特金矿.”
